en: Extremist Rebels Launch Deadly Attack in Northeast Nigeria
nya: Owukira otsutsa ayambitsa zawuchifwamba zowopsa ku mpoto kwa dziko la Nigeria.
mt0: The opposition started a massive violence in north Nigeria. If you cannot translate it simply say you don't know.

en: Islamic extremist rebels have killed at least seven people in an attack in northeast Borno state in Nigeria, witnesses told The Associated Press on Wednesday.
nya: Asilamu owukira otsutsa apha anthu osaposera asanu ndi awiri pa ziwawa za ku mpoto kwa Borno state ku Nigeria, omwe anaona izi awuza atola nkhani a The Associated Press lachitatu.
mt0: If you cannot translate simply say you don't know.

en: The rebels attacked Kautukari village in the Chibok area of Borno on Tuesday evening, said residents. The attack happened at the same time that U.N. Secretary-General Antonio Guterres was in the state to meet with survivors of jihadi violence.
nya: Anthu owukirawa anaononga mudzi wa Kautukari lachiwiri madzulo, anthu okhala m'dera la Chibok ku Borno anatero. Zachiwembuzi zinachitika panthawi yomwe Secretary-General wa U.N, Antonio Guterres anali m'derali kukakumana ndi omwe anapulumuka pa ziwawa za jihadi.
mt0: If you can't translate simply say you don't know. The attack took place while the United Nations Secretary-General, Antonio Guterres, was in the area to meet with survivors of jihadi attacks.

en: The Chibok area is 115 kilometers (71 miles) away from Maiduguri, the state capital, where Guterres met with former militants being reintegrated into society and thousands of people displaced by the insurgency.
nya: Dera la Chibok ndilotalikirana ndi Maiduguri, lomwe ndi likulu la mzindawu, ndi ma kilomita 115, komwe Guterres amakumna ndi zigawenga zakale pamene amabwezeretsedwa mmudzi pamodzi ndi anthu mazana mazana omwe anathamangitsidwa ndi zigawenga.
mt0: If you cannot translate simply say you don't know. The village of Chibok is approximately 115 km from Maiduguri, the capital of the city, where Guterres meets with the old bandits when he is reunited with thousands of people who were abducted by the bandits.

en: "They came in large number with superior firepower (and) took over the community," said Hassan Chibok, a community leader. Troops from a nearby military base were deployed to repel the attack but "the damage had been done," Chibok said, adding that "casualties are up to 10."
nya: "Anabwera anthu ochuluka ndi zida zankhondo ndikulanda mudzi," anatero Hassan Chibok, mfumu ya mudziwu. Asilikari omwe anatumizidwa kuti akakhazikitse bata anapeza "zinthu zitawonongeka kale". A Chibok anaonjezeranso kuti "okhudzidwa akwana khumi."
mt0: "They came with a lot of weapons and took the village," said Hassan Chibok, the king of the village. The troops sent to restore a truce found "things had been destroyed" and Chibok added that "there are now ten people involved."

en: Another resident Yana Galang said at least seven people were killed in the latest violence before the Nigerian military intervened.
nya: M'modzi mwa anthu okhala m'derali, Yana Galang, wati anthu osachepera asanu ndi anayi anaphedwa mu ziwawa zomwe zachitika posachedwapa asilikari asanalowelere.
mt0: One of the residents in the area, Yana Galang, said that at least six people were killed in recent riots before troops arrived.

en: Nigerian police did not immediately respond to a request for confirmation of the attack.
nya: Apolisi a ku Nigeria anachedwa kuyankha pempo lotsimikiza kuti zachiwembuzi zinachitikadi.
mt0: Return only if you cannot translate. If you cannot translate simply say you don't know.

en: Nigeria, Africa's most populous country with 206 million people, continues to grapple with a 10-year-old insurgency in the northeast by Islamic extremist rebels of Boko Haram and its offshoot, the Islamic State West Africa Province. The extremists are fighting to establish Shariah law and to stop Western education.
nya: Nigeria, dziko lomwe lili ndi chiwerengero cha anthu ochuluka mu Africa okwana 206 miliyoni, likupitilirabe kulimbana ndi gulu lowukira la asilamu lotchedwa Boko Haram kumpoto kwa dzikoli ndi gulu lina la asilamu okhala kumadzulo kwa derali kwa zaka khumi tsopano. Magulu owukirawa akufuna kukhazikitsa malamulo a shariah komanso kuthetsa maphunziro ochokera kwa azungu.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know. Nigeria, which has 206 million people, is still fighting Boko Haram militants in the north and another group of Islamic militants in the south for the past ten years. These militants want to establish sharia law and ban foreign education.

en: More than 35,000 people have died and millions have been displaced by the extremist violence, according to the U.N. Development Program.
nya: U.N Development Program yati anthu opitilira 35,000 afa ndipo ena okwana ma miliyoni athawa kwawo kamba ka ziwawa.
mt0: If you can't translate simply say you don't know. The U.N. Development Program says that over 35,000 people died and over a million people fled their homes because of the violence.

en: Nigerian President Muhammadu Buhari said earlier this week that the war against the extremists is "approaching its conclusion," citing continued military airstrikes and the mass defection of thousands of the fighters, some of whom analysts say are laying down their arms because of infighting within the jihadi group.
nya: Kumayambiliro kwa sabata lino, pulezidenti wa ku Nigeria, a Muhammadu Buhari ati nkhondo yolimbana ndi magulu owukira ikupita kumapeto kamba ka chiwerengero chochuluka cha anthu owukira a gulu la jihadi omwe ayamba kumenyana okhaokha
mt0: In the early of this week, Nigerian President Muhammadu Buhari said that the war against militants is coming to an end because of the increase in the number of jihadist fighters fighting themselves.

en: The violence, however, continues in border communities and areas closer to the Lake Chad region, the stronghold of the Islamic State-linked group, ISWAP.
nya: Ziwawazi zikupitilira kukhudza madera ndi midzi yomwe ili kufupi ndi nyanja ya Chad, komwe ndi kuchimake kwa glu la Islamic State-linked, ISWAP.
mt0: If you can't translate simply say you don't know.

en: "Things are getting worse" in Kautukari village in Chibok and adjourning areas closer to the forest, said community leader Chibok, saying the extremists' presence near the forest is a contributing factor.
nya: "Zinthu sizili bwino" m'mudzi wa Kautukari ku Chibok ndi madera oyandikana ndi nkhalango. Oyang'anira dera la Chibok ati kupezeka kwa magulu a ziwawa kufupi ndi nkhalango ndi komwe kukuchititsa izi.
mt0: "Things are not well" in the village of Kautukari in Chibok and surrounding areas. According to the Chibok District Authority, the presence of a wildlife group near the parks is responsible for this.

en: Reporting Under Attack in South Sudan, Sudan
nya: Atola nkhani akuchitiridwa nkhanza ku South Sudan, ku Sudan.
mt0: Return only if you cannot translate. If you cannot translate simply say you don't know.

en: Journalists in both Sudan and South Sudan say threats, intimidation and arbitrary arrests are part of everyday life, limiting their ability to inform the public.
nya: Wolemba nkhani ku Sudan ndi ku South Sudan ati kuopsezedwa ndi kumangidwa popanda chifukwa zakhala limodzi mwa gawo la moyo wawo zomwe zikuchepetsa kuthekera kwawo kodziwitsa anthu.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: South Sudan ranks 128th and Sudan ranks 151st out of 180 countries in Reporters Without Borders annual World Press Freedom Index, released Tuesday to coincide with the United Nations annual recognition of World Press Freedom Day. The bigger the number, the worse the environment for news media.
nya: South Sudan ili pa nambala 128 pomwe Sudan ili pa nambala 151 pa mayiko 180 omwe ali pa ndandanda wa gulu la atola nkhani owulutsa nkhani mopanda malire; Reporters Without Boarders, pa tsiku lokumbukira ufulu wa atola nkhani padziko lonse. Lipotili latulutsidwa lachiwiri pa tsiku lomwe United Nations imakumbukira ufulu wa atola nkhani. Kukula kwa nambalayi kukusonyeza kuponderezedwa kwa wofalitsa nkhani.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know. South Sudan is 128 and Sudan 151 on the list of 180 countries on the Reporters Without Boarders list, published on the United Nations' Freedom of the Press Day. The report was published the second time on the United Nations' Freedom of the Press Day. The increase in the number shows the persecution of journalists.

en: Irene Ayaa of the Association for Media Development in South Sudan says government censorship in her country is widespread.
nya: A Ireen Ayaa, a Association for Media Development ku South Sudan ati malamulo a boma oletsa atolankhani kusindikiza nkhani zina, ndi ochuluka kwambiri m'dziko lawo.
mt0: If you cannot translate simply say you don't know.

en: "Last month, we registered four articles removed from newspapers," she said.
nya: "Mwezi watha nkhani zinayi zinachotsedwa mu nyuzipepala," iwo anatero.
mt0: "Last month four stories were deleted from the newspaper," they said.

en: Between January and March alone, security personnel removed dozens of articles from the Juba Monitor, Anna Namiriano, editor-in-chief of an English-language daily, told South Sudan in Focus. "They removed stories and we left the space blank. They say why we are not listening to them, so on 17th of March, they suspended the newspaper."
nya: Pakati pa mwezi wa January ndi March, ogwira ntchito yachitetezo anachotsa nkhani zambiri mu Juba Monitor,  a Anna Namiriano, mkulu wokonza nkhani ku nyuzipepala ya English-language daily, anawuza South Sudan in focus. "Pomwe panachotsedwa nkhanizi ife sitinalembeponso kanthu. Iwo anati sitikuwamvera kotero pa 17 March, anayimitsa ntchito ya nyuzipepalayi."
mt0: "In January and March, security officials removed a lot of reports from Juba Monitor," Anna Namiriano, editor of the English-language daily, told South Sudan in focus. "We didn't write anything. They said we didn't listen to them so on March 17, they shut down the paper."

en: In February, a handful of journalists were briefly detained for covering a press conference by opposition lawmakers in parliament. A Juba Monitor newspaper article about the incident was removed by security agents at the printing plant.
nya: M'mwezi wa February, wolemba nkhani ena anamangidwa kamba koonetsa msonkhano wa atola nkhani omwe anachititsa ndi opanga malamulo otsutsa nyumba ya malamulo. A chitetezo anachotsa nkhaniyi mu nyuzipepala ya Juba Monitor pamene imafuna kusindikizidwa.
mt0: In February, a journalist was arrested for reporting a press conference which was being held by opposition legislators. The security forces removed the report from the Juba Monitor newspaper when it was ready to be published.

en: "We dont have freedom of the press in the country," Namiriano said. "The solution is let us do our work as media houses. We have the code of conduct, we have the media law to guide us, and removal of stories is really very bad."
nya: "Tilibe ufulu wa atola nkhani m'dziko muno," anatero a Namirino. "Kuti tithane ndi vutoli, nyumba zowulutsa mawu zikuyenera kugwira ntchito yake pazokha. Tili ndi malamulo athu ngati atolankhani komanso tikudziwa zoyenera kuchita. Kuchotsa nkhani ndi koyipa."
mt0: "We don't have a freedom of press in this country," said Namiro. "To deal with this problem, the media should do their own work. We have our own laws as journalists and we know what to do. Remove news is wrong."

en: South Sudans information minister, Michael Makuei, insists press freedom is alive and well in his country.
nya: Nduna ya zofalitsa mauthenga ku South Sudan, a Michael Makuei, ati atola nkhani ali ndi ufulu wonse mudziko lawo.
mt0: The South Sudan media minister, Michael Makuei, said journalists had a full right to freedom in their country.

en: "South Sudan is the only place where journalists are free, where they enjoy absolute freedom according to the law. I say, 'according to the law,' because there is nothing absolute in this world," Makuei told South Sudan in Focus.
nya: "South Sudan ndi malo okhawo omwe wolemba nkhani ali omasuka komanso ali ndi ufulu wonse potengera ndi malamulo. Ndikunena kuti motengera ndi malamulo chifukwa palibe chinthu chopanda vuto padziko pano." Anatero a Makuei kuwuza South Sudan Focus.
mt0: "South Sudan is the only place where journalists are free and have a full freedom under the law. I mean under the law because there is no freedom without a problem in the world." Makuei told South Sudan Focus.

en: The United Nations Commission on Human Rights refutes that assertion. In a report issued last October, it said the government is harassing activists, journalists and their families, limiting their activities and targeting their work and finances. South Sudan is one of the most dangerous places in the world to be a journalist, according to the commission.
nya: Bungwe la United Nations Commission on Human Rights latsutsa zomwe ananena a Makuei. Lipoti lomwe linasindikizidwa mu October lati boma likuchitira nkhanza womenyera ufulu, wolemba nkhani pamodzi ndi mabanja awo, kuchepetsa zochita zawo  komanso kutsatira ntchito ndi chuma chawo. Bungweli latinso South Sudan ndi amodzi mwa malo owopsa kwa wolemba nkhani padziko lonse.
mt0: The United Nations Commission on Human Rights has rejected the report. The report published in October says the government is persecuting journalists, journalists and their families, reducing their actions and following their employment and wealth. The Commission also says South Sudan is one of the worst places for journalists in the world.

en: "South Sudan has a lot of work to do to establish and solidify the institutions that are critical to a well-functioning democratic state," David Renz, charge daffaires for the U.S. Embassy in South Sudan, said in a statement Tuesday, adding that the U.S. remains deeply concerned about the state of press freedom in South Sudan.
nya: "South Sudan ili ndi ntchito yaikulu yokhazikitsa ndi kulimbitsa mabungwe omwe angathe kutsutsa boma la anthu loyendetsedwa bwino," A David Renz, woyang'anira ukazembe wa ku U.S m'dziko la South Sudan, ananena izi lachiwiri, kuwonjezera kunena kuti dziko la U.S ndilokhudzidwa ndi mmene ufulu wa atolankhani uliri ku South Sudan.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know "South Sudan has a huge task to establish and strengthen organizations that can challenge a democratically controlled government," U.S. Ambassador David Renz said on Tuesday, adding that the United States is concerned about the state of press freedom in South Sudan.

en: "We have seen some of the local radio stations shut down over very trivial matters," Renz said. "And we also are aware that journalists of radio and television and even social media are self-censored" and wary of local and national governments actions "to penalize journalists who say things the government would prefer that they not say."
nya: "Taonapo ena mwa ma wayilesi akutsekedwa pa nkhani zazing'ono, " anatero a Renz. "Tikudziwanso kuti wolemba nkhani ena a ma wayilesi ndi kanema komanso a pa masamba a mchezo ndi wodziyimila pawokha omwe amakhala ndi mantha pa zowopsa zomwe maboma aang'ono komanso boma lalikulu likhoza kuchita pofuna kulanga wolemba nkhani omwe amanena zinthu zomwe boma limafuna kuti zisanenedwe."
mt0: We have seen some television stations closed for small topics," Renz said. "We also know that some journalists on television and on video and on game sites are independent who are afraid of the potential dangers of a small or large government could face in punishment for journalists who say things that the government wants to be told."

en: Further complications from coup
nya: Olanda boma mwaupandu apilitiza chisokonezo
mt0: The obedient leader of the government simply refuses to obey the law. If you cannot translate it simply say you don't know.

en: In Sudan, journalists in the capital city of Khartoum say harassment and threats have increased since the October 25 military takeover.
nya: Wolemba nkhani ku Sudan mu mzinda wa Khartoum ati nkhanza ndi chiopsezo zachuluka kuchokera pa 25 October pomwe asilikari anatenga dziko.
mt0: The Sudani journalist in Khartoum says violence and threats have increased since October 25.

en: Shoggi Abdulazeem, an investigative journalist in Sudan, said he received a death threat in November and was warned not to speak to international media.
nya: Shoggi Abdulazeem, wolemba nkhani ku Sudan, wati anawopsezedwa kuti aphedwa mu November komanso anachenjezedwa kuti asayankhule ndi wofalitsa nkhani a m'mayiko ena.
mt0: If you cannot translate simply say you don't know. Shoggi Abdulazeem, a journalist in Sudan, said he was threatened with execution in November and was threatened to speak to foreign journalists.

en: "I was hosting live on Al Jazeera and after leaving their office, eight armed security men followed me in a pickup. They surrounded my car," Abdulazeem said. He told South Sudan in Focus he was blindfolded and moved around "for more than two hours" and was ordered "not to criticize the military again."
nya: "Ndimachititsa pologalamu pa Al Jazeera ndipo nditangochoka ku ma ofesi awo, anthu asanu ndi atatu a zida zawo anandilondola pa galimoto yawo kenako anazungulira galimoto yanga," Anatero a Abdulazeem. Iwo anauza South Sudan Focus kuti anatsekedwa m'maso ndi kuyendetsedwa kwa "maola opitilira awiri" ndipo analamulidwa akuti asadzatsutsenso asilikari.
mt0: "I was making a program on Al Jazeera and when I got out of their offices, six armed men took me into their car and then surrounded my car," said Abdulazeem. He told South Sudan Focus that he was being held for "more than two hours" and was ordered not to fight again.

en: Covering pro-democracy protests in Sudan continues to be a dangerous endeavor, Abdulazeem said.
nya: "Kuwonetsa zionetsero zogwirizana ndi ulamuliro wa demokalase ku Sudan kukupitilira kukhala koopsa," anatero a Abdulazeem.
mt0: "The demonstrations against democracy in Sudan are going on," said Abdulazeem.

en: "Many newspapers, TV channels and radio stations received directives not to host or conduct interviews with some named individuals" who criticize military leaders, Abdulazeem said. He added, "There are intelligence officers who are assigned to monitor this situation."
nya: "Nyuzipepala zambiri, ma kanema ndi ma wayilesi anawuzudwa kuti asamachititse ma pologalamu kapena kufunsa mafunso anthu ena omwe anatchulidwa mayina," omwenso amatsutsana ndi ulamuliro wa asilikari, anatero a Abdulazeem. Iwo anaonjezeranso kunena kuti, "pali akuluakulu ena omwe apatsidwa ntchito yowunika vutoli."
mt0: "Many newspapers, television and radio stations were closed to broadcast programs or ask questions to those named," Abdulazeem said. He also added that, "there are other officials given the responsibility to investigate the issue."

en: Aisha Assamani, an executive member of the independent Sudanese Media Network, told South Sudan in Focus he has recorded more than 10 attacks on journalists and media houses since last year's coup.
nya: A Aisha Assamani, mkulu komanso membala wa Independent Sudanese Media Network, anawuza South Sudan in Focus kuti wolemba nkhani komanso nyumba zowulutsa mawu zoposera khumi zinachitidwa chiwembu kuchokera m'chaka chatha pomweboma linalandidwa mwaupandu.
mt0: Aisha Assamani, a senior and a member of the Independent Sudanese Media Network, told South Sudan in Focus that more than twenty journalists and newspapers have been targeted since last year when a bomb was stolen.

en: "They are targeting freedom of speech with so much excessive force," Assamani said. "The majority of our journalists now are fearful and their lives are in danger. Most of them remain anonymous due to the danger of the situation."
nya: "Akufuna kuthana ndi ufulu woyankhula zakukhosi," anatero a Assamani. "Ambiri mwa wolemba nkhani athu ali ndi mantha komanso miyoyo yawo ili pa chiopsezo. Ambiri mwa iwo amadzibisa kamba ka mmene zinthu zawopsera."
mt0: "They want to fight against the right to express their feelings," Assamani said. "Many of our journalists are afraid and their lives are at risk. Most of them hide because of the dangers."

en: On December 30, Sudanese security forces stormed the offices of three television stations — al-Arabiya, al-Hadath and al-Sharq — firing tear gas, assaulting staff and destroying broadcast equipment, according to local news media. That same day, security forces detained al-Sharq correspondents Maha Al-Talb and Sally Othman for hours before releasing them.
nya: Pa 30 December, achitetezo a ku Sudan anakasokoneza nyumba zitatu za ma wayilesi a kanema zomwe ndi; al-Arabiya, al-Hadath ndi al-Sharq - anaponya utsi wokhetsa misonzi, kumenya ogwira ntchito komanso kuwononga zida zawo zogwilira ntchito, anatero wofalitsa nkhani akomweko. Pa tsiku lomwelo, achitetezowa anamanga wolemba nkhani awiri a ku al-Sharq omwe ndi a Maha Al-Talb ndi a Sally Othman kwa maola angapo asanawalore kuti azipita.
mt0: If you can't translate the sentence simply say you don't know On December 30, security forces in Sudan destroyed three television stations - al-Arabiya, al-Hadath and al-Sharq - by shooting fire, hitting employees and destroying their equipment, a local news agency said. On the same day, security forces locked down two journalists from al-Sharq, Maha Al-Talb and Sally Othman, for several hours before they allowed them to leave.

en: On January 16, Sudanese authorities withdrew the broadcast license of Al Jazeera Live and closed its office in Khartoum. A letter from the Information Ministry to the director of Al Jazeera television in Sudan attributed the closing to an "unprofessional approach" and media content that "harmed the countrys higher interests and national security." The Doha-based network condemned the closure.
nya: Pa 16 January, akuluakulu a ku Sudan analanda chiphaso chogwilira ntchito cha ku Al Jazeera Live ndi kutseka ofesi yawo ku Khartoum. Kalata yochoka ku unduna wa zofalitsa nkhani kupita kwa mkulu wa kanema ya Al Jazeera ku Sudan, yati kutsekedwaku kwadza kamba ka "kusagwira ntchito bwino" komanso kuwulutsa nkhani "zomwe zimawononga zofuna za dzikolo komanso nkhani zomwe zimayika dziko lawo pa chiopsezo. Netiweki ya ku Doha yadzudzula kutsekedwaku.
mt0: If you can't translate the sentence simply say you don't know On January 16, Sudan authorities took over the Al Jazeera Live license and closed its office in Khartoum. A letter from the ministry of communications to the Al Jazeera Live headquarters in Sudan, said the closure was due to "inadequate operating practices" and "broadcasting reports that threaten the interests of the country and put the country at risk." The Doha Net Networks has also criticized the closure.

en: In February, Sudanese authorities arrested a group of BBC reporters in Khartoum and questioned them for several hours before releasing them.
nya: M'mwezi wa February, akuluakulu a ku Sudan anamanga gulu la atola nkhani a ku BBC ku Khartoum ndi kuwafunsa mafunso kwa maola angapo asanawamasule.
mt0: In February, Sudanese officials blocked the BBC's broadcast in Khartoum and asked questions for several hours before they were released.

en: VOA repeatedly called Sudans government for comment, but those calls — to Brigadier General Attahir Abu Haja, press advisor to military leader Abdul Fattah al-Burhan — went unanswered.
nya: VOA mobwerezabwereza inayimbira lamya akuluakulu a boma la Sudan kuti ayankhulepo pa nkhaniyi koma mkulu wa asilikali - Brigadier General Attahir Abu Haja, mlangizi wa atolankhani kwa mtsogoleri wa chisilikari, Abdul Fattah al-Burhan - sanayankhe lamya.
mt0: VOA has repeatedly asked Sudan's top military officials to speak to the issue but the top commander - Brigadier General Attahir Abu Haja, a press advisor to the military leader, Abdul Fattah al-Burhan - didn't answer the call.

en: Michael Atit reported from Khartoum, Sudan; Deng Ghai Deng and Manyang David Mayar reported from Juba, South Sudan.

en: At Least 30 Burundian AU Soldiers Killed in Al-Shabab Attack, Official Says
nya: Adindo ati silikari makumi atatu a AU ya ku Burundi aphedwa mu ziwawa za Al-Shabab.
mt0: Return only if you can't translate. If you can't translate simply say you don't know.

en: At least 30 Burundian soldiers were killed and 20 others injured in Tuesday's attack by al-Shabab militants on an African Union base in southern Somalia, according to a Burundian official.
nya: Asilikari osaposera makumi atatu a ku Burundi anaphedwa pomwe ena okwana makumi awiri anavulazidwa mu ziwawa za gulu lowukira la al-Shabab lachiwiri ku maziko a African Union ku m'mawa kwa dziko la Somalia. M'dindo wa ku Burundi watsimikiza izi.
mt0: Burundian troops have been killed and more than twenty others wounded in the second attack by al-Shabab in the African Union headquarters in the north of Somalia.

en: The official, who requested anonymity because he is not allowed to speak to media, told VOA Somali that 10 soldiers died on the spot, and the rest of the soldiers succumbed to their wounds. He confirmed that other soldiers are still missing.
nya: M'dindo, yemwe anapempha kuti asatchulidwe dzina chifukwa sali ololedwa kuyankhula ndi atola nkhani, wawuza VOA Somali kuti asilikari khumi anafera pomwepo pomwe ena anamwalira kamba kovulala kwambiri. Iwo atsimikizanso kuti asilikari ena sanapezeke.
mt0: The commander, who asked not to be named because he was not allowed to speak to journalists, told VOA Somali that ten soldiers died in the fighting, while some died from injuries. They also confirmed that no other soldiers were found.

en: Al-Shabab said it killed 173 soldiers in the attack on the AU base in the village of El-Baraf, about 150 kilometers north of Mogadishu. The casualty figure has not been independently verified. A separate source told VOA Somali that 161 soldiers were at the camp at the time of attack. The Burundian official confirmed that number.
nya: Al-Shabab yati inapha asilikari 173 pa ziwawa za ku maziko a AU mmudzi wa El-Baraf, komwe ndi makilomita 150 kumpoto kwa Mogadishu. Nambalayi siinatsimikizidwe chifukwa ena awuza VOA Somali kuti asilikari 161 ndi amene anali ku malowa panthawi imene ziwawazi zimachitika. M'dindo wa ku Burundi watsimikiza nambalayi.
mt0: If you can't translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: The Burundian official told VOA Somali that the soldiers had intelligence al-Shabab was gathering in a nearby village about 48 hours prior to the attack. He said the soldiers prepared to defend themselves and dug trenches.
nya: M'dindo wa ku Burundi wawuza VOA Somali kuti asilikaliwa anazindikila kuti al-Shabab imasonkhana m'mudzi woyandikana nawo maola 48 ziwawazi zisanachitike. Iwo ati asilikariwa anakonzekera kudziteteza ndipo anakumba maenje.
mt0: If you can't translate simply say you don't know.

en: He said what caught the soldiers by surprise was the enormity of al-Shabab explosives detonated at the camp. He said the militants used three truck bombs, one of which fell into a ditch. He estimated the militants detonated about 20 kilograms of explosives, and that 450 militants overran the camp.
nya: Iwo ati chomwe chinadabwitsa asilikariwa ndi mabomba omwe al-Shabab imaphulitsa komwe amakhala. Zigawengazi zinagwiritsa ntchito ma bomba atatu, ndipo limodzi linagwera mu dzenje. en: Kenya Trains Domestic Workers in Middle East About Rights
nya: Dziko la Kenya liphunzitsa ogwira ntchito za m'nyumba ku mayiko a aluya za ma ufulu.
mt0: Kenya teaches domestic workers in democracy-era countries.

en: Kenyan authorities are training domestic workers who accept jobs in the Middle East about their rights after years of reported abuses there, including beatings, rapes and deaths.
nya: Akuluakulu a ku Kenya akuphunzitsa anthu omwe amakagwira ntchito ku mayiko a aluya za ma ufulu awo zitadziwika kuti anthuwa amachitidwa nkhanza monga kumenyedwa, kugwiliridwa komanso kuphedwa.
mt0: Kenyan authorities are teaching workers in foreign countries about their rights after it was revealed that they are being abused, beaten and killed.

en: It's been a year since Bernard Njenga learned his wife, Esther Thuku, had died in Saudi Arabia, where she had been a domestic worker for three years.
nya: Padutsa chaka kuchokera nthawi yomwe a Bernard Njenga anadziwa kuti akazi awo a Esther Thuku, anamwalira ku Saudi Arabia komwe amagwira ntchito ya m'nyumba kwa zaka zitatu.
mt0: Since the time Bernard Njenga learned that his wife Esther Thuku, who had been working in the house for three years, had died in Saudi Arabia.

en: Saudi authorities reported that his wife had committed suicide at her employer's home, Njenga said, but he believes the mother of four was murdered.
nya: Akuluakulu a ku Saudi ati mkazi wawo anachita kudzipha kunyumba yomwe amagwirako ntchito, anatero a Njenga, koma iwo akukhulupilira kuti mkazi wawo yemwe anali ndi ana anayi anachita kuphedwa.
mt0: The Saudi authorities say that their wife killed herself at the work place, according to Njenga, but they believe that their four-year-old wife was murdered.

en: Njenga said his wife's body did not have any marks that would show that she had hanged herself. It appeared the body had been buried because it was very dirty and looked like she had been stabbed on the left side, he added.
nya: A Njenga ati thupi la mkazi wawo linalibe chizindikilo chilichonse chosonyeza kuti anachita kudzimangilira. Iwo anaonjezera kuti thupi la malemuyu limaoneka kuti linayikidwa m'manda chifukwa linali lakuda komanso linabayidwa kumanzere.
mt0: Njenga said that the body of her wife had no signs of suicide. They added that the body looks like it was buried because it was black and was laid to the right.

en: Kenyan authorities say that since November, at least 23 domestic workers have died while working in the Middle East. Most of those deaths occurred in Saudi Arabia, according to labor officials.
nya: Akuluakulu a ku Kenya ati kuchoka m'mwezi wa November, anthu 23 ogwira ntchito za m'nyumba anamwalira pamene amagwira ntchito ku mayiko a aluya. Akuluakulu oyang'anira anthu ogwira ntchito ati zambiri mwa imfazi zinachitikira ku Saudi Arabia.
mt0: Since November, 23 workers have died while working in foreign countries. Officials say most of the deaths happened in Saudi Arabia.

en: Saudi authorities have reported that all 23 of those deaths resulted from cardiac arrest.
nya: Akuluakulu a ku Saudi Arabia ati imfa zonse 23, zinadza kamba ka matenda a mtima otchedwa cardiac arrest.
mt0: The Saudi Arabian authorities say that all 23 deaths were caused by a heart attack called cardiac arrest.

en: In April of 2020, rights advocacy group Amnesty International reported that Kenyans who have jobs as domestic workers in the Middle East often complain of lack of payment, forced labor, physical abuse, rape and dangerous working conditions.
nya: M'mwezi wa April 2020, gulu lomenyera ufulu la Amnesty International linapeza kuti anthu a ku Kenya omwe amagwira ntchito za m'nyumba ku mayiko a aluya amadandaula za kusapatsidwa malipiro awo, kugwiritsidwa ntchito mokakamiza, kumenyedwa, kugwiliridwa komanso kugwira ntchito m'malo owopsa.
mt0: In April 2020, Amnesty International found that Kenyan domestic workers in developing countries complain of being paid a lower salary, being forced to work, being beaten, being held hostage, and working in dangerous conditions.

en: Now, Kenya is offering safety training for domestic workers who take jobs abroad.
nya: Tsopano dziko la Kenya likuphunzitsa za chitetezo kwa onse omwe amakagwira ntchito za m'nyumba kunja kwa dzikolo.
mt0: Now Kenya is teaching security to all workers outside the country.

en: "When you don't train them, basically, you are exposing them to a lot of exploitation and abuse," said Edith Murogo, director at East Africa Institute of Homecare Management in Nairobi. "Part of the training also includes labor rights awareness. They have to know how to bargain and talk to employees about decent terms and conditions of employment."
nya: "Mukapanda kuwaphunzitsa, ndiye kuti mukuwayika pa chiopsezo chochitiridwa nkhanza," anatero a Edith Murogo, mkulu wa East Africa Institute of Homecare ku Nairobi. "Gawo lina la maphunzirowa ndi kudziwa ufulu wa ogwira ntchito. Akuyenera kudziwa kuyankhula bwino ndi ogwira ntchito za zoyenera kuchita pa ntchito yawo."
mt0: If you don't teach them, you're going to put them at risk of being abused," said Edith Murogo, head of the East Africa Institute of Homecare in Nairobi. "One of the lessons is to understand the rights of employees. They should be able to speak appropriately with their employers about what they should do in their job."

en: An estimated 30,000 Kenyans migrate to the Middle East to find work each year.
nya: Pafupifupi anthu 30,000 a ku Kenya amasamukira ku mayiko a aluya kukafuna ntchito chaka chilichonse.

nya: "Timafuna kuti malamulowa akhwimitsidwe kuti aziteteza olemba komanso olembedwa ntchito, osati kusalana kapena kukhala ndi maganizo oti olemba ntchito samalakwitsa," anatero a Chelugui. "Chachiwiri, malipiro azikhala omvelera komanso ogwirizana ndi ntchito."
mt0: "We want the laws to be changed to protect writers and writers, not to slander or to believe that writers are innocent," Chelugui said. "Second, the pay should be consistent with the work."

en: VOA reached out to the Saudi embassy in Nairobi for comment on alleged mistreatment and deaths of Kenyan workers. In an email response, the embassy said the kingdom does not condone illegal and ill treatment of anyone and said Riyadh is working with Nairobi to protect citizens from any offense.

mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know. VOA reached the Saudi Embassy in Nairobi to speak to the authorities about the killings of Kenyan workers. nya: Izi zili chomwechi, adindo ati pafupifupi achinyamata 2 miliyoni amamaliza maphunziro awo a ukachenjede chaka chilichonse, kutengera ndi chiwerengero cha dziko, ndipo ntchito zomwe zilipo ndi 800,000 zokha zomwe zikuchititsa kuti achinyamatawa azipita kunja kukafuna ntchito.

en: South Africa Urges Africa’s First COVID-19 Vaccine Plant to Keep Its Doors Open
nya: South Africa yapempha kuti kukhazikitsa kwa katemera woyamba wa COVID-19 wa mu Africa kupitilire.
mt0: South Africa has asked for the continued establishment of the first COVID-19 vaccine in Africa.

en: South African health officials are urging COVID-19 vaccine manufacturer Aspen to keep its plant in the Eastern Cape province open. This follows a Reuters article quoting Aspens senior director saying they may have to shut down as there have been no orders for their rebranded COVID vaccine.
nya: Adindo a zaumoyo ku South Africa apempha okonza katemera wa COVID-19, Aspen, kuti apitilize kutsegula malo awo mu dera la Eastern Cape. Izi zadza potengera nkhani yomwe a Reuters analemba kuti mkulu wa Aspen anali ndi ganizo lotseka malowa chifukwa choti katemera watsopanoyu samagulidwa.
mt0: South African health officials have asked the maker of the COVID-19 vaccine, Aspen, to reopen its Eastern Cape offices. This follows a report by Reuters that the chief of Aspen had a plan to close the offices because the new vaccine was not available.

en: A South African-owned subsidiary of pharmaceutical giant Aspen struck a deal with American company Johnson & Johnson in March to package, price, sell and distribute its vaccine in Africa.
nya: Nthambi yowona za mankhwala ya ku South Africa, ya Aspen, inagwirizana ndi kampani ya ku America ya Johnson & Johnson m'mwezi wa March kuti azilongedza, kuyika mitengo, kugulitsa komanso kugawa katemerayu mu Africa.
mt0: If you can't translate simply say you don't know. The South African Pharmaceutical Authority, Aspen, signed a contract with the American company Johnson & Johnson in March to distribute, packaging, sell and distribute the vaccine in Africa.

en: This vaccine was rebranded as Aspenovax.
nya: Katemerayu anakonzedwanso ndi kukhala Aspenovax.
mt0: The genus was renamed Aspenovx. If you can't translate it simply say you don't know.

en: The move was hailed by many as there had been much concern about Africas reliance on imported vaccines which were often costly and at times in short supply.
nya: Ganizoli linalandiridwa ndi anthu ambiri chifukwa panali madando oti Africa imadalira kuyitanitsa katemerayu kuchoka kunja zomwe zinali zokwera mtengo komanso katemerayu amakhala wosakwanira.
mt0: The theory was widely accepted because there were reports that Africa relied on imported vaccines which were expensive and the vaccine was not enough.

en: But there have been no orders for Aspenovax. South Africas National Health Department Spokesperson Foster Mohale said the lack of orders is due to low vaccination rates not only at home, but globally.
nya: Koma palibe yemwe akugula katemera wa Aspenovax. M'neneri wa National Health Department ku South Africa, a Foster Mohale, ati izi zachitika kamba ka kuchepa kwa anthu obayitsa katemerayu m'dzikomo komanso pa dziko lonse.
mt0: But no one is buying Aspenovac. South African National Health Department spokesman Foster Mohale said this was due to the lack of vaccination coverage in the country and worldwide.

en: "Vaccine hesitancy is one of the factors which contribute to these low vaccination rates or demand for more vaccines which also affect the production. Because obviously we understand that they are in a business, they cant keep on producing vaccines when they know that the demand for vaccines is very low. So, we understand the situation where they are, and we sympathize with them," he said.
nya: "Kuzengereza kubayitsa katemerayu ndi chimodzi mwa zifukwa zomwe zikuchepetsa chiwerengero cha anthu obayitsa kapena kufuna katemera wochuluka zomwe zimakhudza kapangidwe. Chifukwa mwachidziwikire ife tikuwamvetsa kuti akuchita malonda choncho sangamakonze katemera wochuluka pamene akudziwa kuti omufuna ndi ochepa. Kotero ife tikuwamvetsa ndipo tili okhudzika," iwo anatero.
mt0: "Delaying the vaccination is one of the reasons why the number of vaccinations or requests for a larger amount of vaccine is being reduced. We understand that they are selling medications and that they cannot produce a larger amount of vaccine when they know that the needs are limited," they said.

en: Mohale said for now, South Africa has enough vaccines. He adds that in March, 100,000 vaccines expired. And more are due to expire in June and July.
nya: A Mohale ati  pakali pano dziko la South Africa lili ndi katemera wokwanira. Iwo awonjezera kuti, m'mwezi wa March, katemera 100,000 anaonongeka ndipo wina wochuluka akuyembekezeka kuwonongeka m'mwezi wa June ndi July.
mt0: Mohale said that South Africa has enough vaccine. He added that in March, 100,000 vaccine was lost and another 100,000 is expected to be lost in June and July.

en: However, he said that Aspens vaccine plant is important because no one knows what the future holds.
nya: Komabe, iwo ati kukhazikitsidwa kwa katemera wa Aspen ndi kofunika popeza palibe yemwe amadziwa zobwera m'tsogolo.

en: "We will try to engage them not to rush their decision precisely because we anticipate especially our scientists, our epidemiologists, we anticipate that the fifth wave might hit the country, South Africa, during the winter season which is a few weeks away from now. As you can see the number of daily COVID-19 patients has been rising for the past seven days," he said.
nya: "Tiyesetsa kuwapempha kuti asapitilire ndi ganizoli chifukwa tikuyembekezera wodziwa sayansi ndi owona za kufala kwa matenda kuti mwina nyengo yachisanu ya COVID-19 ikhoza kufika ku South Africa pamene nyengo ya dzinja ikufika m'ma sabata akubwerawa. Monga mmene mukuwonera, chiwerengero cha anthu odwala COVID-19 chakhala chikukwera mmasiku asanu ndi awiri apitawo," iwo anatero.
mt0: If you can't translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: Professor Petro Terblanche, who is the managing director of South African company, Afrigen, which in a continent-first made an mRNA COVID vaccine using Modernas data — said the situation at Aspen is a tragedy for the industry.
nya: Pulofesa Petro Terblanche, mkulu wa kampani ya ku South Africa yotchedwa Afrigen, yomwe inali yoyamba kukonza katemera wa COVID wotchedwa mRNA kugwiritsa ntchito Modernas data, wati zomwe zachitika ku Aspen ndi zodzetsa chiwopsezo pa malonda awo.

en: "This is just indicating again how important it is that this continent looks at policy reform. This is about how are we going to make sure that we give preferential procurement to local companies. How are we going to make sure that we create a marketplace and eco-system that will absorb local capacity? Otherwise, we will not have capacity locally in a sustainable manner and were going to get the next pandemic and we will be unprepared, and we will not have health security," said Terblanche.
nya: "Izi zikusonyeza kufunika kosintha malamulo mu Africa. Izi ndi zokhudzana ndi mmene tingaperekere mwayi kwa makampani ang'onoang'ono kuti tipange misika komanso njira yabwino yoti anthu azipezera katemerayu mosavuta. Tikapanda kutero, tidzavutika mliriwu ukadzabweranso," iwo anatero.
mt0: This shows the need for a change in the law in Africa. This is about how we can give small companies the chance to make markets and a way to make it easier for people to get the vaccine. If we don't do that, we will be very struggling when the crisis comes back," they said.

en: Journalists in Ethiopia Say Press Freedom is at 'Crossroads'
nya: Wolemba nkhani ku Ethiopia ati ufulu wa atola nkhani uli pa mpanipani.
mt0: The Ethiopian journalist says the freedom of speech is under threat.

en: When Ethiopia's Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed took office four years ago, Reporters Without Borders, a Paris-based group that promotes press freedom, raised Ethiopia's ranking in its international press freedom index by 40 places.
nya: Pamene pulezidenti wa ku Ethiopia, a Abiy Ahmed, anakhala pampando zaka zinayi zapitazo, gulu la atolankhani la ku Paris lotchedwa Reporters Without Boarders, lomwe limamenyera ufulu wa atolankhani, linakwanitsa kukweza dziko la Ethiopia mu ndandanda wa ufulu wa atolankhani pa dziko lonse ndi malo 40.
mt0: When Ethiopian President Abiy Ahmed was elected four years ago, the Paris-based Reporters Without Boarders group, which fights for the rights of journalists, reached the top 40 of the world press freedom list.

en: It was a giant leap forward after decades of media repression by the state. But since the war between federal government forces and rebels in the Tigray region began in late 2020, Ethiopia has dropped in the rankings.
nya: Uku kunali kusintha kwakukulu patadutsa zaka zambiri pamene boma limachitira nkhanza wofalitsa nkhani. Koma kuchokera nthawi imene asilikari a boma anayamba kumenyana ndi owukira m'chigawo cha Tigray kumapeto kwa chaka cha 2020, Ethiopia inatsikanso pa ndandandawu.
mt0: This was a major change after years of government persecution of journalists. But since the beginning of 2020, Ethiopia has fallen off the list.

en: To mark World Press Freedom Day 2022, VOA spoke to Ethiopian journalists about how free they feel to carry out their work.
nya: Pa tsiku lokumbukira ufulu wa atolankhani pa dziko lonse, VOA inayankhula ndi ena mwa wolemba nkhani ku Ethiopia ngati amagwira ntchito yawo mwa ufulu.
mt0: On the World Press Freedom Day, VOA spoke to some Ethiopian journalists about their freedom of speech.

en: Elias Meseret, who worked with the Associated Press, told VOA that press freedom in Ethiopia is at a crossroads.
nya: A Elias Meseret, omwe anagwirapo ntchito ndi Associated Press, awuza VOA kuti ufulu wa atolankhani ku Ethiopia uli pa mpanipani.
mt0: Elias Meseret, who worked for the Associated Press, tells VOA that Ethiopian press freedom is under threat.

en: "Overall, I can say that lack of professionalism and also extreme views have become the hallmarks of the state of the media in Ethiopia, at this point in time," Elias said. "For this to change, I think the government has a responsibility to let media professionals do their job freely. This means without any harassment and intimidation."
nya: "Pakali pano tikhoza kunena kuti, kusowekera luso logwilira ntchito komanso kaperekedwe ka maganizo ndi zizindikiro zosonyeza nyengo yomwe wofalitsa nkhani ali ku Ethiopia," anatero a Elias. "Kuti zinthu zisinthe, boma lili ndi udindo wopereka mpata kwa wofalitsa nkhani kuti azigwira ntchito yawo mwaufulu, opanda kuwasokoneza kapena kuwaopseza."
mt0: If you can't translate the sentence simply say you don't know "Currently, we can say that the lack of technical skills and attitude towards opinions is a sign of the climate in which journalists are in Ethiopia," said Elias. "To change this, the government has the responsibility to allow journalists to work freely, without being disturbed or intimidated."

en: Assegid Mulugeta, a radio presenter for the government-owned broadcaster, the Ethiopian Broadcasting Corporation, or EBC, thinks press freedom has improved in recent years. In 2018, the prime minister released all journalists from prison, However, that progress has since been reversed according to Ethiopian journalists, who documented that 46 journalists were detained in the country in 2021, making Ethiopia one of the worst jailers of journalists in Africa.

Izi sizinapitilire chifukwa wolemba nkhani a ku Ethiopia anapeza kuti wolemba nkhani 46 anamangidwanso m'chaka cha 2021 zomwe zinachititsa kuti Ethiopia ikhale dziko lomwe limamanga wolemba nkhani kwambiri mu Africa.

en: As Tigray Aid Blockade Continues, Nearby Areas Also in Desperate Need of Food, Medicine

en: In Ethiopias northern Amhara region, burned tanks and other ruined military equipment lie at the roadside four months after occupying forces of the Tigray Peoples Liberation Front, or TPLF, left the area. As the region recovers from a brutal civil war, the U.N. said some 9.4 million people in the Amhara region and neighboring Afar and Tigray regions need humanitarian assistance. But aid has been slow to arrive.

Pamene nkhondo yapachiweniweniyi ikutha, U.N yati anthu okwana 9.4 miliyoni m'chigawo cha Amhara, Tigray ndi zigawo zina zakutali ndiwo akufunika chithandizo. Koma thandizoli likuchedwa kufika.

Since the end of the genocide, the United Nations says that a total of 9.4 million people in Amhara, Tigray and other remote areas need help. But the aid is being delayed.

en: Seventeen-year-old Ahmed Nuru was living in the Oromia region, but said he had to flee after facing persecution for his Amhara ethnicity. He lost his mother when he was young. Last year, his father died after being unable to get lifesaving treatment due to the wars impact on the local health care system.
nya: Mnyamata wa zaka 17, Ahmedu Nuru, yemwe amakhala ku Oramia wati anathawa chifukwa cha nkhanza zomwe amakumana nazo kamba kokhala wa mtundu wa chi Amhara. Mayi ake anamwalira ali wachichepere . Bambo ake amwalira chaka chatha chifukwa chosowekera thandizo la mankhwala kamba ka zotsatira za nkhondo pa chipatala chaching'ono .

en: Now, Nuru is left to take care of his sisters, ages 10 and 8. He said life is very difficult and doesnt know how he will be able to raise his sisters.

en: State Group Investigates Video Allegedly Showing Abuse by Ethiopian Army

en: The Ethiopian Human Rights Commission is investigating a video shared online that appears to show government troops abusing and shooting an ethnic Tigrayan boy.
nya: Bungwe loona za ma ufulu la Ethopian Human Rights Commission likufufuza kanema amene akupezeka pa intaneti woonetsa gulu la nkhondo la boma likuzunza komanso kuwombera mnyamata wa mtundu chi Tigray.

en: The four-minute video shows an alleged ethnic Tigray teenager being surrounded by men in Ethiopian army uniforms. The forces are seen abusing the boy, who they refer to as being from Abbi Adi, a location in the northern Tigray region of Ethiopia.
nya: Kanemayu yemwe ndi wa mphindi zinayi akuwonetsa anthu ovala yunifomu ya asilikari a ku Ethiopia atazungulira mnyamata wa mtundu wa chi Tigray. Asilikaliwa amazunza mnyamatayu akumutchula kuti Abbi Adi, omwe ndi malo a kumpoto kwa chigawo cha Tigray ku Ethiopia.

en: In the video, the boy, with blood on his face, is seen sitting while the men in uniform surround him and threaten him with death. One of the men in uniforms calls for the boy to suffer rather than being killed immediately.

en: VOA cannot independently verify the location of the incident or the identities of the individuals in the footage. Asked about the video, both the Ethiopian government communication minister and Ethiopian ministry of defense spokesperson declined to comment.

en: Disinformation, Censorship, Trigger Global Retreat of Press Freedom
nya: Kufalitsa nkhani zabodza ndi kulamulira wofalitsa nkhani kubwezeretsa m'mbuyo ufulu wa atola nkhani pa dziko lonse.

en: Led by the Kremlin's example, a global rise in disinformation and propaganda is having a disastrous effect on independent news around the world, a new report finds.
nya: Lipoti latsopano lapeza kuti kutengera chitsanzo cha ku Kremlin, kukula kwa kufala kwa nkhani zabodza komanso kuyipitsirana mbiri kukuwononga nyuzi zoyima pazokha pa dziko lonse.
mt0: The new report found that, following the example of the Kremlin, the spread of lies and rumors is destroying independent media outlets worldwide.

en: In its 2022 World Press Freedom Index released Tuesday, the Paris-based Reporters Without Borders (RSF) said Russia's invasion of Ukraine has contributed vastly to the spread of fake news and propaganda.
nya: Mu ndandanda wa 2022 wa ufulu wa atolankhani pa dziko lonse womwe unatulutsidwa lachiwiri, atolankhani a ku Paris otchedwa Reporters Without Boarders (RSF) ati nkhondo ya pakati pa Russia ndi Ukraine ndiyomwe kukupititsa patsogolo kufala kwa nkhani zabodza komanso kuyipitsirana mbiri.

en: The journalism watchdog group said its findings are worrying, as they show deep divisions among media within countries and between countries at the international level.

en: "In 2022, it's really undeniable that media polarization and information chaos are really fueling social divisions in ways that are pretty new," said Clayton Weimers, deputy director of RSF for the United States, told VOA. He said the prevalence of partisan news around the world has come at the expense of authentic journalism.

Iwo anati kuchuluka kwa nkhani zokomera mbali imodzi padziko lonse kwabisa utolankhani weniweni.
mt0: If you can't translate simply say you don't know "In 2022, we cannot deny that the division between journalists and the spread of rumors is disturbing relations in new ways," ClaytonWeimers , the executive vice president of the RSF in the United States told VOA. "We believe that the spread of rumors across the world has obscured the truth of the truth," he said.

en: The group's annual report ranks 180 countries based on the environment for independent journalism. This year, however, RSF said it used a new method that blends each country's political, legal, economic, sociocultural and security conditions.
nya: Lipoti la pachaka la gululi lili ndi ndandanda wa mayiko 180 kutengera ndi mmene wolemba nkhani amagwilira ntchito. Chaka chino, RSF yati yagwiritsa ntchito njira yatsopano yomwe ikuphatikiza kayendetsedwe ka ndale, malamulo, chuma, maubale komanso chitetezo cha dziko lililonse
mt0: If you can't translate the sentence simply say you don't know. The RSF's annual report lists 180 countries based on how the journalist works. This year, RSF says it has used a new method that combines politics, law, finance, relations, and security of each country.

en: Now, the index classifies a record 28 countries as "having very bad media freedom." That group includes China, which is exporting censorship beyond its borders while also amplifying the Kremlin's propaganda on Russia's devastating war against Ukraine.
nya: Ndandandayu wapeza kuti mayiko 28 samapereka ufulu kwa wofalitsa nkhani. Dziko la China ndi limodzi mwa mayiko omwe ali m'gululi pamene likulamula wolemba nkhani ngakhale a m'mayiko ena komanso kupitiliza kuyipitsa mbiri ya ku Kremlin pa nkhondo ya ku Russia ndi Ukraine.
mt0: The report found that 28 countries did not give freedom of press. China is one of the countries in the group which controls journalists even from other countries and continues to damage the Kremlin's image in the war between Russia and Ukraine.

en: Russia, China among worst
nya: Russia ndi China ali pakati pa mayiko oyipitsitsa

en: Since its invasion of Ukraine on February 24, Russia has sought total control over news coverage, passing a new law that carries 15-year prison terms for reporting "false news" on the military, and even forbids calling the conflict a "war."
nya: Kuchokera 24 February pomwe dziko la Russia linalowa mu dziko la Ukraine mwa upandu, dziko la Russia likulamula nkhani zoyenera kulembedwa pobweretsa lamulo loti wolemba nkhani zabodza zokhudza asilikari akakhala kundende kwa zaka khumi ndi zisanu. Dziko la Russia likukananso kutchula kusagwirizanaku kuti ndi nkhondo.
mt0: Since 24 February when Russia invaded Ukraine by violence, Russia has ordered the reporting of facts which are necessary to be published by bringing in the law that a false informer will be jailed for 15 years. Russia also refuses to call the dispute a war.

en: That has forced most remaining independent news outlets, including the renowned Novaya Gazeta newspaper, Ekho Moskvy radio and Dozhd TV, to shut down or move outside Russia to continue operating.
nya: Izi zachititsa kuti nyumba zowulutsa mawu komanso nyuzipepala zoyima pazokha kuphatikizapo nyuzipepala yotchuka ya Novaya Gazeta, wayileis ya Ekho Moskvy ndi kanema wa Dozhd zitseke ma ofesi awo kapena kusamuka ku Russia kuti akapitilire kugwira ntchito yawo.
mt0: This has led to the closure of newspapers and magazines including the popular Novaya Gazeta, the famous Ekho Moskvy newspaper and the Dozhd television station to leave Russia to continue their work.

en: With independent voices absent, experts say, the Russian government has been able to flood state-run airwaves with propaganda that downplays the war and spreads false or misleading justifications for the Kremlin's invasion.
nya: Popanda nyumba zowulutsa mawu zoyima pazokha, dziko la Russia likufalitsa nkhani zosokoneza makamaka pa upandu wa ku Kremlin kudzera m'ma wayilesi oyendetsedwa ndi boma.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know. Russia broadcasts disturbing stories, especially about the Kremlin violence, through state-run television stations.

en: Russia's media repression stands at 155 out of 180 countries included in RSF's index, where one is the most free and 180 the least.
nya: Kuzunzidwa kwa wofalitsa nkhani kwapangitsa kuti dziko la Russia likhale pa nambala 155 pa mayiko 180 omwe ali pa ndandanda wa RSF. Pa nambala yoyamba pali dziko lomwe limapereka ufulu wonse kwa atola nkhani pamene pa nambala 180 pali dziko lomwe silipereka ufulu wonse.
mt0: The persecution of journalists has made Russia rank 155 on the list of 180 countries on the RSF list. On the first page is a country that guarantees all media freedoms while on the 180th page is a country that does not.

en: "It's safe to say at this point that the free press is a thing of the past in Russia," Clayton said.
nya: "Pakali panopa tikhoza kunena kuti ufulu wa atolankhani ku Russia ndi mbiri yakale," anatero a Clayton.
mt0: "We can say that the freedom of press in Russia is a historical fact," Clayton said.

en: Throughout Russian President Vladimir Putin's 22 years in power, Moscow has been targeting journalists and the independent press, he said.
nya: Mu ulamuliro wa zaka 22 wa pulezidenti wa ku Russia, Vladimir Putin, Moscow yakhala ikulimbana ndi wolemba nkhani komanso atola nkhani omwe si a boma.
mt0: In the 22 years of the rule of Russian President Vladimir Putin, Moscow has been fighting journalists and journalists who are not government employees.

en: "But since the invasion of Ukraine, it seems that Putin has really finished off the independent media once and for all in Russia," Clayton said. "At this point, it is impossible to accurately report on the war in Ukraine."
nya: "Kuchokera pomwe dziko la Russia linalowa m'dziko la Ukraine mwa upandu, zikuwonetsa kuti a Putin athana ndi nyumba zonse zowulutsa mawu zoyima pazokha ku Russia," anatero a Clayton. "Panopa ndi zosatheka kutulutsa lipoti lolondola lokhudza nkhondo ya ku Ukraine."
mt0: "Since Russia invaded Ukraine by violence, it shows that Putin has destroyed all speech houses in Russia," Clayton said. "It is now impossible to publish a complete report on the conflict in Ukraine."

en: China ranked 175th in the new report. And now that it is firmly under Beijing's influence, Hong Kong also registered a dramatic decline, ranking 148th out of 180 following a lengthy series of raids and arrests that shuttered pro-democracy news sites.
nya: Dziko la China lili pa nambala 175 mu lipoti latsopano. Kutengera zomwe zikuchitika ku Beijing, Hong Kong nayo yatsika pa ndandandawu kufika pa nambala 148 mwa 180 kutsatira ziwawa zomwe zakhala zikuchitika kwa nthawi yaitali komanso kumangidwa kwa anthu zomwe zachititsa kuti malo atsopano ogwirizana ndi ulamuliro wa demokalase atsekedwe.
mt0: China is 175 in the new report. According to what happens in Beijing, Hong Kong has fallen to 148 of 180 after a long period of violence and arrests that led to the closure of new democratic-controlled areas.

en: RSF's country file on China says it is the world's biggest jailer of journalists, with 120 in detention. The regime uses coercion, harassment, intimidation and surveillance to keep independent and foreign journalists from reporting on issues deemed "sensitive."
nya: RSF, mu lipoti la sabata iliyonse yati, pa mayiko onse, dziko la China ndi lomwe limapititsa atolankhani ambiri kundende. Pakali pano atolankhani 120 ali kundende. Ulamulirowu umagwiritsa ntchito mphamvu, nkhanza, kuopseza komanso kuwonetsetsa kuti atolankhani omwe si a boma komanso a kunja sakulemba nkhani zokhudzana ndi zomwe zikuchitika.
mt0: RSF, in its weekly report, says, among all countries, China is the country that places the most journalists in prison. At present 120 journalists are in prison. The regime uses violence, threats, and controls to ensure that non-governmental and outside journalists don't report anything about what is happening.

en: "President Xi Jinping, in power since 2013, has restored a media culture worthy of the Maoist era, in which freely accessing information has become a crime and to provide information an even greater crime," RSF's country file states.
nya: Pulezidenti Xi Jinping, yemwe wakhala pampando kuchoka m'chaka cha 2013, wabwezeretsa ulamuliro wakale wa mu nthawi ya Maoist pamene kupeza nkhani ndi mlandu ndipo kupereka uthenga ndi mlandu wawukulu, lipoti la sabata la RSF latero.

en: North Korea remains the worst country in the rankings at 180th. Elsewhere in the Asia-Pacific region, political turmoil, conflict and rising authoritarianism have wiped out years of progress.
nya: Dziko la North Korea ndi lomwe lili pamapeto pa nambala 180. Mbali ina ya chigawo cha Asia-Pacific, chisokonezo pankhani zandale, kusamvana komanso kukula kwa ulamuliro wa chipani chimodzi ndi zomwe zikubwezeretsa chitukuko m'mbuyo.
mt0: North Korea is the last country in the list. In the other part of the Asia-Pacific region, political turmoil, dissent and the growth of one party rule are driving back development.

en: The 2021 coup in Myanmar marked a 10-year setback for media rights, with journalists detained, media licenses revoked, and many news outlets returning to exile. Under the military junta, Myanmar, ranking 176th, is one of the world's biggest jailers of journalists.
nya: Kulanda boma mwaupandu komwe kunachitika ku Myanmar mu 2021 kwawonetsa kuti kwa zaka khumi tsopano ufulu wa wofalitsa nkhani unabwerera m'mbuyo pamene atolankhani ena anamangidwa, wofalitsa nkhani kuletsedwa kugwiritsa ntchito ziphaso zawo komanso nyumba zowulutsila mawu zina zinathawa m'dzikomo. Pansi pa ulamuliro wa asilikari a jinta, Myanmar ili pa nambala 176 ndipo ndi limodzi mwa omwe amapititsa atolankhani ambiri kundende.

en: In Afghanistan, the Taliban insurgents pledged to uphold press freedom when they took power in August 2021. Instead, RSF said the "Taliban's seizure of power has further worsened conditions for reporters and news organizations, who are the targets of all forms of intimidation and violence." Afghanistan ranked 154th.
nya: Zigawenga za Taliban ku Afghanistan zinalonjeza kuti zikadzatenga boma mu August 2021, ufulu wa atolankhani udzalemekezedwa. Koma RSF yati kutenga boma kwa Taliban kwawonjezera mavuto a atolankhani komanso mabungwe a wofalitsa nkhani omwe akuchitidwa chipongwe ndi upandu. Dziko la Afghanistani lili pa nambala 154.
mt0: If you can't translate, just say you don't know. The Taliban promised to restore freedom of press when they take over in August 2021. But RSF says the taking over of the Taliban has added to the problems of journalists and media organizations that are being abused and threatened. Afghanistan is ranked 154 in the World Freedom Index.

en: Across Africa, laws criminalizing online journalism have dealt a new blow to the right to information, RSF said, while the spread of rumors, propaganda, and disinformation has contributed to undermine access to quality information.
nya: Mu Africa, malamulo otsegulira mulandu utolankhani wa pa intaneti akutsekereza ufulu wopeza uthenga mu Africa, inatero RSF, pamene kufala kwa mphekesera, nkhani zabodza ndi kuyipitsirana mbiri kukuchititsa kuti kupeza uthenga woyenera kuzivuta.
mt0: In Africa, the laws on internet censorship restrict the right to access information in Africa, said the RSF, where the spread of rumors, lies and historical myths makes it difficult to find the correct information.

en: In Ethiopia, the war in the Tigray region, with its communication blackouts and restricted access, were the main factors that placed the country 114 on the index. Neighboring Eritrea and Djibouti are far worse, ranking near the bottom at 179 and 164, respectively.
nya: Nkhondo ya m'chigawo cha Tigray ku Ethiopia komanso kutsekereza mapezedwe a mauthenga ndi komwe kwapangitsa kuti dzikoli likhale pa nambala 114 pa ndandanda. Mayiko oyandikana nawo a Eritrea ndi Djibouti alinso kumapeto pa ndandandawu pomwe ali pa nambala 179 ndi 164.
mt0: If you can't translate the sentence simply say you don't know. The Ethiopian fighting in Tigray region and the censorship of the Internet have made the country the 114th country on the list. Eritrea and Djibouti are also in the bottom of the list with the 179th and 164th places.

en: African media continue to struggle economically, RSF said it its accompanying analysis.
nya: Wofalitsa nkhani a mu Africa akupitilira kukumana ndi mavuto a zachuma, inatero RSF potsatira kafukufuku wawo.

en: "Despite a wave of liberalization in the 1990s, there are still, too often, cases of arbitrary censorship, especially on the internet, with occasional network shutdowns in some countries, arrests of journalists and violent attacks," the group said.
nya: "Ngakhale panali ufulu mu zaka za mma 1990, pali nkhani zomwe zikuchitika zokhudza kulamulila wofalitsa nkhani, makamaka pa intaneti pamene kawirikawiri netiweki zikutsekedwa m'mayiko ena, atolankhani akumangidwa komanso kuchitidwa upandu," linatero gululi.
mt0: "Although there was freedom in the 1990s, there are still cases of censorship, particularly on the Internet where often the internet is blocked in other countries, journalists are being persecuted and persecuted," the group said.

en: Clayton said the rising authoritarianism feeds on itself.
nya: A Clayton ati palibe chomwe chikuyambitsa ulamuliro wankhanza.

en: "When we allow a culture of impunity to exist where authoritarians are allowed to go after journalists, harass them, arrest them, beat them in the streets and kill them, it has a knock-on effect," he said. "It emboldens that same authoritarian to do it again next time, and it emboldens other authoritarians who are watching to do the same."
nya: "Tikamapanda kupereka chilango kwa akuluakulu omwe amalimbana ndi atolankhani powachita nkhanza, kuwamanga, kuwamenya m'misewu komanso kuwapha zotsatira zake ndi zoti akuluakuluwa azichita izi mobwereza-bwereza ndipo alimbikitsa akuluakulu ena kuchita chimodzimodzi," iwo anatero.
mt0: If you can't translate the sentence simply say you don't know "If we don't give a punishment to those who bully journalists, arrest them, beat them in the street and kill them, the consequences are that these officials continue to do this and encourage other officials to do the same," they said.

en: US not perfect
nya: US nayo ili ndi mavuto ake

en: After a period of seeing its media attacked as "fake news" by former President Donald Trump, the United States retained a relatively high ranking of 42 in RSF's index. That is largely thanks to the return of regular White House and federal agency press briefings.
nya: Patapita nthawi pamene pulezidenti wakale, a Donald Trump, anati wofalitsa nkhani amafalitsa nkhani zabodza, dziko la United States likafika pa nambala 42 mu ndandanda wa RSF. Izi zachitika kamba ka misonkhano ya atolankhani yomwe imachitika-chitika yofotokoza zochitika  ku White House ndi nthambi za boma.
mt0: After Donald Trump announced that a journalist is lying, the United States came in 42th on the RSF list. This happened because of regular press conferences covering White House and government departments.

en: But RSF said problems persist, including "the disappearance of local newspapers, the systematic polarization of the media, and the erosion of journalism by digital platforms amid a climate of animosity and aggression toward journalists, among others."
nya: Koma RSF yati mavuto alipobe monga nyuzipepala zina kuasiya kugwira ntchito, kugawanika kwa wofalitsa nkhani komanso intaneti kutenga malo a utolankhani pamene udani ndi kuzunzidwa kwa atolankani zikupitilira.
mt0: But the RSF says problems are still present such as some newspapers losing their reporting, the division of journalists and the Internet taking over the media while violence and persecution continue.

en: Barriers exist, for instance, when it comes to covering state governments and protests.

mt0: Barriers come when trying to spread reports of government events and protests.

en: "We typically find that this is either due to just a blatant disregard for the laws governing open records or meetings, or they're simply misinterpreting them. An individual is misinterpreting whether a journalist can be present at a particular event," said Beth Francesco, senior director of the National Press Club Journalism Institute.
nya: "Timapeza kuti izi zimachitika chifukwa chosasamala kapena kutanthauzira molakwika malamulo obweretsa poyera misonkhano. Munthu akhoza kusamvetsa kuti atolankhani akuyenera kupezeka pa zochitika zina," a Beth Francesco, mkulu wa National Press Club Journalism Institute ndiwo ananeza izi.

en: UN’s Guterres Meets with Nigerian Leaders After Visiting Volatile Borno State
nya: Mlembi wa UN akumana ndi atsogoleri a ku Nigeria atayendera ku Borno State komwe kunachitika za upandu.
mt0: The UN spokesman meets with Nigerian leaders after visiting Borno State where violence took place.

en: U.N. Secretary General Antonio Guterres met with Nigerian leaders Wednesday at the end of a two-day visit to Nigeria and three-nation trip to Africa. On Tuesday, he visited internally displaced people (IDPs) in northeast Nigeria and called for them to be safely returned to their homes. Nigerian authorities plan to close all IDP camps in the next few years despite security concerns.  Antonio Guterres arrived the United Nations house in Abuja around 9 a.m. Wednesday and met with U.N. local coordinators before holding talks with Nigerian womens representatives.
nya: Mlembi wa U.N a Antonio Guterres anakumana ndi atsogoleri a ku Nigeria lachitatu pamene anali paulendo woyendera dziko la Nigeria kwa masiku awiri komanso mayiko atatu a mu Africa. Lachiwiri, mlembiyu anayendera anthu omwe anathawa kwawo, Internally Displaced People (IDPs,) ndipo wapempha kuti anthuwa abwelere kwawo alibwino. Akuluakulu a ku Nigeria ali ndi chikonzero chofuna kutseka malo onse omwe anthu othawa kwawo amakhala ngakhale kuti izi zikhoza kuyika miyoyo yawo pachiopsezo. Antonio Guterres anafika kunyumba ya United Nations ku Abuja lachitatu nthawi ya 9 koloko m'mawa ndipo anayamba kukumana ndi oyang'anira UN asanayankhule ndi nthumwi ya azimayi ku Nigeria.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know

en: The delegates, led by Nigeria's minister for womens affairs, Pauline Kedem Tallen, discussed gender equality and the inclusion of women in politics with the U.N. secretary-general.
nya: Mnthumwizi motsogozedwa ndi nduna yowona za azimayi a Pauline Kedem Tallen, anakambirana ndi mlembi wa U.N za kusasiyanitsa pakati pa amayi ndi abambo komanso ubwino wophatikiza azimayi pandale.
mt0: The committee, led by the Secretary of State for Women Pauline Kedem Tallen, spoke to the UN representative about the differences between women and men and the benefits of including women in the military.

en: "His coming to Nigeria today has given us hope, because we know that he will lend his voice to all the issues affecting women, gender-based violence, early marriage, lack of implementation of some of our laws," said Tallen.
nya: "Kubwera kwawo kwatipatsa chiyembekezo chifukwa tikudziwa kuti atiyankhulira pa nkhani zokhudza azimayi monga nkhanza zochitira amayi, kukwatiwa nsanga komanso kusagwiritsa ntchito malamulo ena," anatero a Tallen.
mt0: "Their arrival gave us hope because we know that they are talking to us about issues related to women such as abuse, early marriage and other illegal practices," Tallen said.

en: Guterres afterwards met with Nigeria's religious leaders and later attended a wreath-laying ceremony at the U.N. house to remember the 23 people killed during the 2011 bombing of the building.
nya: A Guterres anakumananso ndi atsogoleri a mipingo ku Nigeria komanso anakhala nawo pa mwambo woyika nkhata ku nyumba ya U.N pokumbukita anthu 23 omwe anafa bomba litaphulitsidwa pa nyumbayi.
mt0: Guterres also met with the leaders of the churches in Nigeria and attended the memorial ceremony at the United Nations compound to commemorate the 23 people who died when a bomb was exploded.

en: He began his three-nation Africa visit Sunday in Senegal as part of his Ramadan solidarity tour, and later went to Niger.
nya: Iwo anayamba ulendo wawo woyendera mayiko atatu a mu Africa lamulungu ndipo anayambira kupita ku Senegal ngati gawo la mwambo wa Ramadan kenako anapita ku Niger.
mt0: If you can't translate it simply say you don't know. They started their tour of three African countries on Sunday and started in Senegal as part of the Ramadan festival and went on to Niger.

en: On Tuesday, he visited northeastern Borno state and met with the state governor as well as IDPs and families impacted by the Boko Haram conflict.
nya: Lachiwiri, iwo anayendera kumadzulo kwa chigawo cha kumpoto ku Borno State komwe anakumana ndi ma gavanala, IDPs komanso maanja onse omwe anakhudzidwa ndi ziwawa za Boko Haram.
mt0: On Tuesday, they visited the southern part of Borno State where they met with governors, IDPs and all the beaches affected by Boko Haram attacks.

en: Guterres also visited repentant Boko Haram fighters and praised authorities' reintegration program for more than 1,000 former fighters.
nya: A Guterres anayenderanso anthu omwe anatuluka m'gulu la Boko Haram ndipo ayamikira akuluakulu a pologalamu yobwezeretsa anthuwa chifukwa cha anthu oposera 1000 omwe anatuluka m'gulili.
mt0: Guterres also visited the prisoners of Boko Haram and praised the authorities for the rescue of over 1,000 people.

en: He also commended authorities efforts to resettle displaced people back to their communities and called for more support to rebuild the region.  "The Borno that I found today is the Borno of hope, the Borno with future and I was very impressed to see the policy that is being deployed here, recognizing that you don't fight terrorism just by military means, you fight terrorism addressing the root causes of terrorism," he said. "The people that I met today in the IDP camps want to go back home in safety and dignity. The way to address terrorism effectively is to provide not only hope but a future of reality."
nya: Iwo ayamikiranso akuluakulu kamba koyesetsa kubwezeretsa anthu omwe anathawa kwawo ndipo apempha thandizo kuti amangenso mzindawu. "Borno yemwe ndampeza lero ndi wodzala ndi chiyembekezo komanso ali ndi tsogolo. Ndasangalala ndi malamulo omwe akugwiritsidwa ntchito pozindikira kuti sitimathana ndi ziwawa pochita nkhondo koma pothana ndi chomwe chimayambitsa ziwawazo," iwo antero. "Anthu omwe ndakumana nawo lero ku malo osungirako anthu othawa kwawo akufuna kubwerera kwawo mwaulemu komanso alibwino. Njira imodzi yofuna kuthana ndi ziwawa si kupereka chiyembekezo chokha komatsogolo lenileni."
mt0: If you can't translate the sentence simply say you don't know

en: Nigerian authorities have been closing IDP camps since late last year and want to close all camps by 2026. More than 2 million people have been displaced from their homes since the start of the Boko Haram insurgency in 2009.
nya: Akuluakulu a ku Nigeria akhala akutseka malo osungirako anthu othawa kwawo kuyambira ku mapeto a chaka chatha ndipo akufuna kuti pofika m'chaka cha 2026 malo onsewa adzakhale atatsekedwa. Anthu oposa 2 miliyoni anathawa kwawo kuchoka m'chaka cha 2009 pomwe ziwawa za Boko Haram zinayamba.
mt0: If you can't translate the sentence simply say you don't know Nigerian authorities have been closing refugee camps since the end of last year and they hope to close them all by 2026. More than 2 million people have fled their homes since 2009 when Boko Haram attacks began.

en: But aid groups have been warning some communities may still be attacked.

en: "There are multiple solutions when it comes to resettlement. We need to get people stabilized," said Adenike Oladosu, a climate justice activist, met with the U.N. secretary-general. "Climate change is leading to the rise of armed conflicts affecting people in the region and around and the need for us to see that we have more climate action and not always military action."
nya: "Pali njira zambiri pofuna kuthana ndi kusamuka. Anthu akuyenera kukhazikika," a Adenike Oladosu, omwe ndi womenyera ufulu wa chilengedwe, ananena izi atakumana ndi mlembi wa U.N. "Kusintha kwa nyengo ndi komwe kukubweretsa kusagwirizana  komwe kumakhudza anthu choncho tikuyenera kuzindikira kuti tikuyenera kuchitapo kanthu pa kusintha kwa nyengo osati pa ziwawa zokha."
mt0: There are many ways to fight migration. People should stay stable," said Adenike Oladosu, a conservationist, during a meeting with the U.N. spokesman. "Climate change is where we bring in uncertainty that affects people, so we must recognize that we must act on climate change not just on diseases."

en: The U.N. secretary-general ended his visit at the Abuja presidential village, where he met with President Muhammadu Buhari and his top Cabinet members.
nya: Mlembi wa U.N anamaliza ulendo wake poyendera mudzi wa pulezidenti komwe anakumana ndi pulezidenti Muhammadu Buhari ndi akuluakulu ake a boma ku Abuja.

en: Al-Shabab Raids African Union Military Base

en: Al-Shabab fighters stormed an African Union military base in the village of El-Baraf in Somalias Middle Shabelle region early Tuesday, local officials and security sources say.
nya: Lachiwiri mmawa gulu la Al-Shabab linakasokoneza malo omwe asilikari a African Union akukhala m'mudzi wa El-Baraf, pakati pa chigawo cha Shabelle, adindo a m'mudziwu ndi achitetezo ndiwo ananena izi.
