nya: Adindo awuza VOA Somali kuti zigawengazi sizinakhalitse pamalowa. Wofalitsa nkhani a boma ati asilikari a ku Burundi omwe anali pamalowa anathawa.
mt0: The officials told VOA Somali that the attacks did not reach the border. A government press officer said Burundian troops had fled.

en: "The Federal Government of Somalia condemns in the strongest possible terms the heinous attack targeting the African Union Transition Mission in Somalia forward operating base in Elbaraf, Middle Shabelle," the Somali Ministry of Foreign Affairs posted on its official Facebook page.
nya: "Boma la ku Somalia likudzudzula mtchitidwe woyipa wolimbana ndi asilikari a African Union Transition Mission ku Somalia omwe akukhala ku Elbaraf, pakati pa Shabelle," unduna woona zakunja ku Somalia unanena izi pa tsamba lawo la mchezo la Facebook.
mt0: "Somalia's government condemns the actions of the African Union Transition Mission in Somalia against the troops based in Elbaraf, between Shabelle," the Foreign Ministry of Somalia said on its Facebook page.

en: "We extend our deepest condolences to the victims of this terrorist attack and their families."
nya: "Tikupepesa onse omwe akhudzidwa ndi ziwawazi komanso mabanja awo."
mt0: We apologize to all those affected by the flood and their families.

en: The Mayor of El-Baraf, Abdullahi Haji Muhumed, said the militants started their attack with two suicide truck bombs. He said the militants then fought their way onto the base.
nya: Mfumu ya mzinda wa El-Baraf, a Abdullahi Haji Muhumed, ati zigawengazi zinayamba upanduwu pophulitsa mabomba awiri kenako kupita komwe kunali asilikari.
mt0: The king of El-Baraf, Abdullahi Haji Muhumed, said the assailants started the attack by shooting two bombs and then going to a military base.

en: Al-Shabab claimed the killing of 173 African Union forces. The group also claimed responsibility for capturing AU forces as prisoners-of-war. Both claims could not be independently verified. AU force headquarters and Somali military officials could not be immediately reached for comment.
nya: Al-Shabab yati inapha asilikari 173 a African Union. Gululi lavomerezanso kuti ndilo linagwira asilikari a AU kuti akhale akaidi awo owathandizira kumenya nkhondo, koma izi sizinatsimikizidwe. Likulu la asilikari a AU komanso adindo a asilikari a ku Somali sanapezeke kuti ayankhulepo pa nkhaniyi.
mt0: If you can't translate, just say you don't know. Al-Shabab claims to have killed 173 African Union soldiers. The group also claims to have held soldiers of the African Union as prisoners of war, but this has not been confirmed. The AU headquarters and the Somali military officials did not appear to be available to comment on the incident.

en: In an interview with VOA, Muhumed, who was not at the village at the time of the attack, said he was told there were "many deaths" among Burundian forces but could not give an exact figure.
nya: Poyankhula ndi VOA, a Muhumed ati iwo sanali m'mudzimu pamene ziwawazi zimachitika. Iwo ati, "inali nkondo yoopsa."
mt0: When speaking to VOA, Muhumed said he was not in the heavens when the explosions took place. He said, "It was a very dangerous weapon."

en: "Fighting like this never happened in this area," he said. "It was heavy fighting."
nya: "Sitinaonepo nkhondo ngati imeneyi," iwo anatero. "Inali nkhondo yayikulu."
mt0: "We've never seen such a war," they said. "It was a big war."

en: He said two civilians were also killed and more than 10 others injured.
nya: Iwo anati anthu awiri anaphedwa ndipo ena oposera khumi anavulazidwa.
mt0: They said two people were killed and more than twenty were injured.

en: Muhumed confirmed to VOA that al-Shabab militants withdrew from the base. He also reported airstrikes targeting the militants as they left the base but did not say who was responsible for the strikes.
nya: A Muhumed atsimikizira VOA kuti zigawenga za Al-Shabab zinachokadi kumalowa. Iwo anenanso kuti panthawi yomwe zigawengazi zimachoka pamalopa, panali ndege zomwe zimawalondola koma sanatchule mwini wa ndegezo.
mt0: The spokesman confirmed to VOA that the militants of Al-Shabab had gone out of the city. He also said that when the militants left the city, there were planes flying towards them but he didn't say who they were.

en: El-Baraf, approximately 150 kilometers north of Mogadishu, is one of the forward operating bases of African Union forces from Burundi.
nya: El-Baraf, yomwe ili pafupifupi makilomita 150 kumpoto kwa Mogadishu, ndi limodzi la madera omwe asilikari a African Union ochokera ku Burundi amakhalako.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know El-Baraf, which is about 150 km north of Mogadishu, is one of the areas where African Union troops from Burundi live.

en: The incident marked the first major al-Shabab attack on AU forces since the mission changed its name and operational structures last month.
nya: Aka kanali koyamba kuti Al-Shabab ichite zaupandu kwa asilikari a AU kuchokera nthawi yomwe AU inasintha dzina komanso magwiridwe ake a ntchito mwezi watha.
mt0: This is the first time that Al-Shabab has attacked AU forces since they changed their name and procedures last month.

en: The U.N. Security Council, which authorized the new mission called the African Union Transition Mission in Somalia (ATMIS), gives it a mandate to reduce the threat posed by al-Shabab, support the capacity-building of Somali security forces, and conduct a phased handover of security responsibilities to Somalia. The mission has until the end of 2024 to operate in the country.
nya: Khonsolo ya chitetezo ya U.N, yomwe inapereka chilolezo kwa bungwe latsopano la African Union Transition Mission in Somalia (ATMIS), lapereka ulamuliro kwa bungweli kuti lichepetse ziopsezo za Al-Shabab, kuthandiza kuwonjezera chiwerengero cha asilikari a ku Somalia komanso kusiya udindo wachitetezo mmanja mwa dziko la Somalia. Bungweli likhala likugwira ntchito m'dzikomo mpaka kumapeto kwa chaka cha 2024.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know. The United Nations Security Council, which granted the permission for the new African Union Transition Mission in Somalia (ATMIS), gave the authority to the organization to reduce the threat posed by Al-Shabab, to help increase the number of troops in Somalia and to leave security responsibilities in the hands of Somalia. The organization will continue to work in the country until the end of 2024.

en: India’s Muslims Mark Eid al-Fitr Amid Community Violence
nya: Asilamu a ku India achita chikondwelero cha Eid al-Fitr nthawi ya ziwawa.
mt0: If you can't translate it simply say you don't know.

en: Muslims across India marked Eid al-Fitr on Tuesday by offering prayers outside mosques, even as the celebrations this year came in the backdrop of a series of recent attacks against the community during the month of Ramadan.
nya: Asilamu m'dziko la India amakondwelera Eid al-Fitr lachiwiri pochita mapemphero panja pa mizikiti yawo ngakhalekuti chikondwerelo cha chaka chino chinali ndi zovuta zake kutsatira zachiwembu zomwe zinachitika m'derali m'mwezi wa Ramadan.
mt0: If you can't translate, just say you don't know. Muslims in India celebrate Eid al-Fitr on Tuesday by praying outside their mosques despite the difficulties of this year's celebrations following the riots in the region in Ramadan.

en: "We will not have the same kind of festivity" this time, said Mohammad Habeeb ur Rehman, a civil engineer in Indias financial capital, Mumbai. "This is the most painful Eid with worst memories for Indian Muslims."
nya: "Sitidzakhalanso ndi chikondwelero cha mtundu wotere," a Mohammad Habeeb ur Rehman, omwe amagwira ntchito yoyang'anira mamangwidwe a zinthu ku Mumbai ndiwo ananena izi. "Eid imeneyi ndiyowawa chifukwa ikukumbutsa asilamu a ku India zomwe zinachitika."
mt0: "We will never have such a holiday," Mohammad Habeeb ur Rehman, a worker at the inventory control office in Mumbai, said. "This Eid is sad because it reminds the Indian Muslims of what happened."

en: Anti-Muslim sentiment and attacks have surged across the country in the last month, including stone throwing between Hindu and Muslim groups during religious processions and subsequent demolitions of a number of properties mostly belonging to Muslims by authorities.
nya: Kudana ndi asilamu komanso ziwembu zakhala zikuchitika m'dzikoli mwezi watha kuphatikizapo kugendana miyala pakati pa anthu a mtundu wa chi Hindu ndi magulu a asilamu mapemphero ali nkati komanso akuluakulu kugwetsa nyumba za asilamu
mt0: If you cannot translate simply say you don't know.

en: The community, which makes up 14% of Indias 1.4 billion population, is reeling from vilification by hard-line Hindu nationalists who have long espoused an anti-Muslim stance. Some leaders of Indias ruling Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party have tacitly supported the violence, while Prime Minister Narendra Modi has so far been silent about it. Eid al-Fitr is typically marked with communal prayers, celebratory gatherings around festive meals and new clothes, but celebrations in India for the past two years have been marred by COVID-19 restrictions.
nya: Anthu 14 pa 100 aliwonse mu chiwerengero cha anthu 1.4 billion a ku India amachokera m'derali. Anthu a mtundu wa chi Hindu akhala akuyipitsa mbiri ya derali kamba koti amadana ndi asilamu. Atsogoleri a chipani cholamula cha Bharatiya Janata, chomwe ndi cha anthu a mtundu wa chi Hindu, akuthandizira nawo ziwawazi mwakachetechete pamene pulezidenti Narendra Modi sanayankhulepo kanthu pankhaniyi. Pokondwerela Eid al-Fitr, pamakhala mapemphero, maphwando komanso zovala zatsopano koma mu zaka ziwiri zapitazi, mwambowu wakhala ukusokonekera kamba ka ziletso za COVID-19 ku India.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know

en: In Indian-controlled Kashmir, the Muslim festival has been subdued for the past three years because of an unprecedented military lockdown after India stripped the regions semi-autonomy in 2019, followed by the pandemic. The region also saw a rise in violence during Ramadan, with at least 20 militants, two civilians and five police and soldiers killed.
nya: Mwambo wa asilamu ku India wa Kashmir wakhala usakuchitika kwa zaka zitatu zapitazo kamba ka ziletso zomwe zinabwera pofuna kupewa mliri wa COVID-19. Ziwawa zambiri zinachitika panthawi ya Ramadan pomwe zigawenga makumi awiri, anthu awiri, apolisi asanu komanso asilikari anaphedwa.
mt0: If you can't translate, just say you don't know.

en: "As we prepare to celebrate Eid, a strong sense of collective loss jars at us," said Bashir Ahmed, a businessman in Srinagar.
nya: "Pamene tikukonzekera kusangalala mwambo wa Eid, tikumakhala ndi chikumbumtima cha imfa," anatero a Bashir Ahmed wochita malonda ku Srinagar.
mt0: If you can't translate, just say you don't know.

en: Kashmir is the Muslim-majority disputed region where a violent insurgency against Indian rule and New Delhis brutal crackdown has raged for over three decades. Tens of thousands of people have died in the conflict.
nya: Kashmir ndi chigawo chomwe chili ndi asilamu ochuluka, komwenso kwakhala kuli ziwawa zowukira ulamuliro wa ku India, komanso kuchitiridwa nkhanza kwa mzinda wa New Delhi kwa zaka zoposa makumi atatu.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know Kashmir is a region with a large Muslim population, where there have been riots against Indian rule, and the persecution of New Delhi for more than thirty years.

en: Meanwhile in the capital, New Delhi, hundreds assembled in the Jama Masjid, one of Indias largest mosques, while offering Eid prayers there for the first time in over two years due to pandemic restrictions. Families came together early on Tuesday morning while many people shared hugs and wishes.
nya: Izi zili chomwechi, anthu mazana mazana anasonkhana ku umodzi mwa mizikiti yayikulu ku India, ku Jama ku New Delhi, kuchita mapemphero a Eid koyamba mu zaka ziwiri kamba ka ziletso za mliri wa COVID-19. Mabanja anabwera pamodzi lachiwiri mmawa ndipo kunali kukumbatirana ndi kuuzana zofuna.
mt0: This is the case, hundreds of people gathered in one of the biggest mosques in India, Jama in New Delhi, to pray Eid for the first time in two years because of the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic. Families came together on Tuesday morning and there was a hug and a shared wish.

en: Beijing Residents Brace for COVID-19 Lockdown
nya: Anthu okhala ku Beijing akonzekera m'bidikiro wa COVID-19.

en: Unlike Shanghai, Beijing has yet to require that all its residents remain at home to contain the spread of COVID-19. Nevertheless, many people in its Chaoyang district and elsewhere are preparing for that possibility.
nya: Kusiyana ndi ku Shanghai, okhala ku Beijing akuyenera kukhala kunyumba kuti apewe kufala kwa COVID-19. Komabe anthu ambiri okhala m'boma la Chaoyang ndi kwina konse akukonzekera chiletsochi.

en: On Wednesday, city officials closed 60 subway stations, more than 10% of Beijing's vast system. They did not say when service would be resumed, according to ABC News.
nya: Lachitatu, adindo a mzindawu anatseka malo 60 okwelera sitima omwe amatenga 10% ya gawo ya zinthu zochitika ku Beijing. ABC News yati akuluakuluwa sananene nthawi yomwe malowa adzapitilire kugwira ntchito.

en: Beijing, a city of 21 million people, has been on high alert for the spread of COVID-19, as restaurants and bars pivot to takeout, gyms close and schools suspend classes indefinitely, according to CNBC.
nya: Beijing, mzinda womwe uli ndi anthu 21 miliyoni, uli tcheru pofuna kupewa kufala kwa COVID-19 pamene malo ogulitsa zakudya ndi malo omwera mowa sakulola ogula awo kudyera kapena kumwera mowa pamalo pomwepo. Malo olimbitsirako thupi komanso sukulu zatsekedwa kaye, CNBC yatero.

en: People who live in "controlled" areas, neighborhoods where cases have been discovered, have been told to stay in the city, and all residents must test for the virus three times throughout the week, according to ABC.
nya: Anthu amene akukhala malo amene kwapezeka odwala COVID-19 ndi malo ena ozungulira, awuzidwa kuti akhalebe mumzindawu ndipo akayezetse ngati ali ndi matendawa katatu msabatayi, ABC yatero.

en: Chinese authorities reported 5,489 cases nationwide on Wednesday, of which 4,982 were in Shanghai, which has been under a draconian lockdown for weeks.
nya: Akuluakulu a ku China ati pa anthu 5,489 omwe apezeka ndi COVID-19 m'dzikomo, anthu 4,982 anali ku Shanghai, dera lomwe anthu analetsedwa kuyenda kwa ma sabata angapo tsopano.
mt0: If you can't translate, just say you don't know.

en: Beijing reported 46 symptomatic cases and five asymptomatic on Wednesday. The city's total since April 22, what it considers the start of its omicron outbreak, is 544.
nya: Anthu 46 a ku Beijing ndi amene amaonetsa zizindikiro za matendawa pamene anthu asanu samawonetsa zizindikiro zilizonse lachitatu. Kuchokera pa 22 April, kwa nthawi yoyamba mzindawu unapeza kuti anthu 544 akudwala mtundu wina wa COVID-19 wotchedwa omicron.
mt0: If you cannot translate, just say you don't know 46 people in Beijing are reported to have symptoms of the disease while five people show no symptoms on the third day. Since April 22, the city has reported that 552 people have contracted the omicron variant of COVID-19.

en: Mr. Zhang, a Beijing resident, said he had bought extra food and water, even though he doesn't think Beijing will be locked down like Shanghai. He asked that VOA not use his full name because he was afraid of attracting official attention.
nya: Bambo Zhang omwe amakhala ku Beijing ati anaguliratu zakudya ndi madzi zoonjezera ngakhale sakuganiza kuti akhoza kuletsedwa kuyenda ngati ku Shanghai. Iwo anapempha VOA kuti isagwiritse ntchito dzina lawo lonse kuopa adindo a m'dzikoli.
mt0: Mr Zhang, who lives in Beijing, said he bought food and water supplies although he didn't think he would be blocked from traveling like in Shanghai. He asked VOA not to use his full name because he feared for their political standing.

en: "I have six bags of rice, two bags of noodles, and several boxes of water, instant noodles and (nutritionally dense) biscuits, and I haven't stocked up too much," Zhang told VOA Mandarin in a phone interview last week. He said he bought his groceries online because the supermarket was crowded.
nya: "Ndili ndi matumba asanu ndi limodzi a mpunga, matumba awiri a ma noodles, mabotolo angapo a madzi ndi mabisiketi osapatsa nthanzi. Sindinasunge zinthu zambiri," a Zhang anawuza VOA Mandarin pa lamya sabata yatha. Iwo anati anagula katundu wawo kudzela pa intaneti chifukwa misika inali yodzadza.
mt0: "I have six bags of rice, two bags of noodles, a few bottles of water and a few empty bottles. I didn't keep a lot of things," Zhang told VOA Mandarin last week.

en: Ms. Yao, who lives in the Chaoyang district, told VOA Mandarin that she had been stocking up on necessities since the beginning of this year, after the Ministry of Commerce recommended that everyone do so. She asked that VOA Mandarin not use her full name because she wanted to avoid official retribution.
nya: A Yao omwe amakhala m'boma la Chaoyang, awuza VOA Mandarin kuti akhala akusunga zonse zofunika kuchokera kumayambiliro a chaka chino pamene unduna wa za kugula ndi kugulitsa unachejeza aliyense kutero. Iwo anapempha VOA Mandarin kuti isagwiritse ntchito dzina lawo lonse kuopa kulangidwa ndi adindo.
mt0: A Yao, who lives in Chaoyang County, told VOA Mandarin that they have kept all the necessary documents since the beginning of this year when the Department of Commerce advised against doing so. They asked VOA Mandarin not to use their full name because they feared being punished by officials.

en: "I have always maintained a good habit of reserving food. So I have a lot of rice, noodles and oil at home," she said, adding that she figured her family would be fine even if Beijing locked down for a month.
nya: "Ndinazolowera kusunga chakudya, kotero ndili ndi mpunga wambiri, ma noodles ndi mafuta ophikira kunyumba," iwo anatero, kuwonjezera kuti atati aletsedwe kuyenda ku Beijing, banja lawo silingasowe kanthu kwa mwezi wathunthu.
mt0: "I've been used to keeping food, so I have a lot of rice, noodles and cooking oil at home," they said, adding that if they weren't allowed to travel to Beijing, their family wouldn't have to miss anything for a month.

en: And while Beijing has not yet closed the city, citizens' lives have been disrupted.
nya: Ngakhale kuti mzinda wa Beijing sunatsekedwe, miyoyo ya anthu yasokonezeka.
mt0: Although Beijing has not been closed, people's lives have been affected.

en: On April 28, the Beijing Chaoyang District Maternal and Child Health Care Hospital issued a notice that the outpatient and emergency departments of the hospital would suspend the admission of patients.
nya: Pa 28 Epulo, chipatala cha amayi ndi ana ku Beijing, m'boma la Chaoyang chinalengeza kuti odwala mwadzidzidzi ndi omwe matenda awo ndi ochepa asiya kugonekedwa pachipatalapo.
mt0: If you can't translate simply say you don't know On April 28, the Beijing Women's Hospital in Chaoyang District announced that emergency patients and those with mild illnesses were being released from the hospital.

en: On the same day, Chaoyang Hospital, one of the largest hospitals in Beijing, announced on its official Weibo account that its emergency department would also suspend the admission of patients. Weibo is China's equivalent of Twitter.
nya: Pa tsiku lomwelo, chipatala cha Chaoyang chomwe ndi chimodzi mwa zipatala zazikulu ku Beijing, chinalengezanso pa tsamba lawo la Weibo kuti akhozanso kusiya kugoneka odwala  mwadzidzidzi. Weibo ili ngati tsamba la mchezo la Twitter ku China.
mt0: The same day, Chaoyang Hospital, one of the largest hospitals in Beijing, announced on its Weibo page that it could temporarily stop seeing patients. Weibo is like a game page on Twitter in China.

en: Angry Chinese netizens left more than 800 messages under the official WeChat account "Beijing Headline."
nya: Anthu okwiya ogwiritsa ntchito intaneti ku China anasiya mauthenga oposa 800 pa tsamba la WeChat pa "zochitika ku Beijing."
mt0: If you can't translate simply say you don't know.

en: "Why do you stop the emergency room as soon as there is a new COVID case, and how many people will be killed due to the secondary disaster caused by the COVID?" a netizen asked in a Weibo post.
nya: "Ndi chifukwa chani mukutseka malo othandizira odwala mwadzidzidzi pamene kwapezeka ena odwala COVID ndipo ndi anthu angati amene angamwalire kamba zotsatira za ngozi yoyambitsidwa ndi COVID?" wogwiritsa ntchito intaneti anafunsa pa tsamba la Weibo.
mt0: "Why are you closing hospitals when there are cases of COVID-19 and how many people can die from the impact of the pandemic?" a user asked on Weibo.

en: Some Beijing residents said they were not worried about a Shanghai-like lockdown.
nya: Ena okhala ku Beijng ati sakudandaula ndi kuletsedwa kuyenda ngati ku Shanghai.
mt0: Some people in Beijing don't complain about the ban on traveling like in Shanghai.

en: "Basically, I'm not afraid," said Mr. Wang, who asked VOA Mandarin to not use his full name so he could avoid attracting authorities' attention. "The party, government and military are here, and the people are here."
nya: "Poyamba ine sindikuwopa," anatero bambo Wang omwe anapempha VOA Mandarin kuti isagwiritse ntchito dzina lawo lonse kuwopa akuluakulu. "Chipani, boma ndi asilikari ali pano, anthunso ali pompano."
mt0: "I don't fear," said Mr. Wang, who asked VOA Mandarin not to use his full name to fear authorities. "The party, the government and the soldiers are here, the people are here."

en: However, Wang told VOA Mandarin, in mid-October last year, after one person in his apartment building was diagnosed as positive, about 600 people from more than 200 families were forced into isolation at several hotels in the Changping district for 21 days.
nya: Komabe a Wang awuza VOA Mandarin kuti pakati pa mwezi wa October chaka chatha, munthu mmodzi atapezeka ndi COVID ku imodzi mwa nyumba zomwe amakhala, anthu 600 ochokera ku mabanja oposera 200, anakakamizidwa kudzipatula pokhala ku ma hotela m'boma la Changping kwa masiku 21.
mt0: But Wang told VOA Mandarin that in October last year, one person found with COVID-19 in one of his houses, 600 families of more than 200, were forced to stay in hotels in Changping for 21 days.

en: Wang and his wife were not allowed to share a room at their hotel.
nya: A Wang ndi akazi awo sanali ololedwa kugona chipinda chimodzi.

en: What particularly puzzled and annoyed Wang was that on the last day of the mandatory hotel quarantine, in addition to routine nasal and oral swabs during testing, authorities added anal swabs to the regimen.
nya: Chomwe chinawadabwitsa ndi kukwiyitsa a Wang ndi choti pa tsiku lomaliza kukhala mokakamizidwa ku hotelayi, kupatula kuyezedwa m'phuno ndi mkamwa, akuluakulu analamula kuti ayezedwenso kudzera ku malo ochitira chimbudzi.

nya: M'mwezi wa March, boma la U.S linalengeza kuti liyesetsa kudziwa komanso kulanda katundu wa anthu a chuma a ku Russia omwe athandiza boma la pulezident Vladmir Putin, ngati gawo losonyeza kukhudzidwa chifukwa cha upandu womwe Moscow inachitira Ukraine pa 24 February.

en: U.S. Attorney General Merrick Garland said Thursday in a statement there is "no hiding place for the assets of criminals who enable the Russian regime." "Now it looks that I believe the*(Britons), and Americans, and the Qataris of course played some role, even the Azeris might have done this. And things are changing and relaxing a bit more, and now at the presidential level, it's going to be sealed."
nya: "Pulezidenti Erdogan ali pa ubale wabwino ndi a mfumu; tinali ndi mavuto aakulu ndi mwana wa mfumu, Muhammad Bin Salman," atero a Ogutcu. mt0: "President Erdogan is in good relations with the king; we had a big problem with the son of the king, Muhammad Bin Salman," said Ogutcu. "Now it seems that I believe that people from Britain, America and Qatar took part even though people from Azerbaijan could have done it." Things are changing and getting better, now that the president's announcement is published.

en: Erdogan and the crown prince have been bitter rivals. The Turkish president led international condemnation over the murder of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi, who was killed inside Saudi Arabias consulate in Istanbul.
nya: A Erdogan ndi mwana wa mfumu akhala pa udani woopsa. Pulezidenti wa chi Turkish ndi yemwe anatsogolera mayiko kudzudzula dziko la Saudi Arabia pa kuphedwa kwa mtolankhani wa ku Saudi, a Jamal Khaashoggi, yemwe anaphedwa mu ofesi ya ku Istanbul ku Saudi Arabia.

en: The killing was linked to the crown prince, a charge he denied. But the decision earlier this month to move the Khashoggi murder trial from Istanbul to Riyadh is seen as a gesture by Ankara, opening the way for Erdogan's visit.

mt0: Ogutcu said that when the presidential election is next year, Erdogan wants Saudi to help boost Turkish economy.

en: "Turkey has an interest in reviving relations with Riyadh because Turkey needs financial support," said Ogutcu. "The Turkish economy is not attracting any significant portfolio investments nor sovereign wealth funds coming to invest Turkey. But this will be a give-and-take package deal involving these countries. So, there are real economic and political security interests involved."
nya: "Turkey ikufuna kuyambitsanso ubale wake ndi Riyadh chifukwa dziko la Turkey likufuna thandizo la ndalama," anatero a Ogutcu. Kotero pali chuma komanso ndale zofunika chitetezo."
mt0: "Turkey wants to re-establish ties with Riyadh because the country needs financial support," said Ogutcu. "The Turkish economy does not attract many groups or investors to do business in the country. But now there is a partnership of giving and receiving between the two countries. So there is financial and political security."

en: Shared concerns over Iran's growing influence in the region -- along with its nuclear energy program -- provide important common ground between Riyadh and Ankara, says international relations professor Soli Ozel of Istanbul's Kadir Has University, especially as American attention is expected to pivot away from the Middle East and toward China.
nya: Pali kudandaula kuti ganizo la dziko la Iran lofuna kupitilira ndi kukhazikitsidwa kwa mphamvu ya nukiliya ndi komwe kukuyanjanitsa Riyadh ndi Ankara, a polofesa Soli Ozel a ku sukulu ya ukachenjede ya Kadir yomwe ili ku Istanbul ndiwo ananena izi. en: "Turkey does propose itself as a counterweight to Iran. en: Erdogan's Saudi visit is part of a wider policy of seeking to repair relations across the region in a bid to end its isolation. The Turkish president has recently visited the United Arab Emirates and earlier this month hosted the Israeli president, Isaac Herzog.

en: Saudi Arabia is pushing to revamp its harsh justice system but reforms are overshadowed by executions and tough treatment of dissidents, raising questions about how much will change.

en: The kingdom is known for its strict interpretation of Islamic sharia law, which forms the basis of its judicial system.

en: But in recent months it has moved ahead with reforms that analysts say could make its courts function more like others in the Middle East.
nya: Koma m'miyezi yapitayi, dzikoli lapitilira ndi kusintha malamulo zomwe akatswiri ati zikhoza kupangitsa kuti makhothi awo azigwira ntchito ngati ena onse ku mayiko a aluya.
mt0: But in the past months, the country has moved on with changes in the law that experts say could allow their courts to work like any other in the developed countries.

en: That effort hinges on a series of new laws for sensitive issues like women's divorce rights and judges' power to determine criminal sentences.
nya: Izi zagwirizana ndi m'ndandanda wa malamulo atsopano okhudza ufulu wa azimayi banja likatha komanso mphamvu ya oweruza milandu kupereka chigamulo kwa olakwa.
mt0: This is consistent with the new list of laws regarding the rights of women after divorce and the power of judges to sentence the guilty.

en: Announced last year by de facto ruler Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, the measures, including the first written penal code, appear to align with Saudi Arabia's goal of opening up to the world and softening its extremist image.
nya: Chaka chatha, mwana wa mfumu, Prince Mohammed bin Salman yemwe anadziika yekha pampando analengeza kuti njira zimenezi kuphatikizapo malamulo omwe analembedwa koyamba okhudzana ndi milandu komanso zilango zake, akufanana ndi cholinga cha Saudi Arabia chofuna kumasukira dziko ndi kuchotsa chithunzithunzi choyipa.
mt0: Last year, the son of the king, Prince Mohammed bin Salman who was sworn in, announced that these steps, including the first written laws relating to cases and punishments, are consistent with the Saudi Arabian goal of opening the country and changing the negative image.

en: Even critics concede the changes could make Saudi courts more predictable, in some cases.

nya: Koma palibe chiyembekezo choti pakhala kufewetsa malamulo okhwima oletsa kuyankhula zakukhosi kapena ngati makhothi asiye kuwonetsa tsankho kwa omwe akuoneka kuti ndi otsutsa boma.

en: And despite the reforms, authorities have simultaneously provided reminders of what gave Saudi Arabia its ruthless reputation in the first place, notably the mass execution of 81 men in a single day in March for offenses related to "terrorism."
nya: Pamene pali kusintha, pa nthawi yomweyo akuluakulu akukumbutsa zomwe zinachititsa kuti Saud Arabia ikhale ndi mbiri yankhanza, ndipo ati izi zili chomcho kamba ka kuphedwa kwa anthu 81 pa tsiku limodzi m'mwezi wa March pa milandu yokhudzana ndi ziwawa.

en: Two new laws have already been approved by the Saudi Cabinet. One governs the admissibility of evidence, previously at the judges' discretion.
nya: Malamulo awiri atsopano avomerezedwa ndi boma la ku Saudi. Lamulo loyamba ndi lolola kupereka umboni wovomerezedwa ndi woweruza milandu.
mt0: Two new laws have been approved by the Saudi government. The first is allowing a certified proof of a court order.

en: The second, a family law, is to take effect in June. In a traditionally male-dominated system, it expands the rights of divorced women to alimony and custody of their children.
nya: Lamulo lachiwiri ndi lokhudza mabanja lomwe liyambe kugwira ntchito mu June. Kutengera pachikhalidwe chomwe abambo amalamula, lamuloli likutambasula ufulu wa amayi wolandila malipiro komanso kusunga ana banja likatha.
mt0: The second law is about marriage which began to apply in June. Based on the rules of the fathers, the law grants mothers the right to receive income and to keep children after the marriage ends.

en: Announcing the new law in March, Prince Mohammed said it represented "a major qualitative leap" for women's rights and "family stability."
nya: Polengeza za lamulo latsopano m'mwezi wa March, Prince Mohammed ati lamuloli likusonyeza "kusintha kwakukulu" pa ufulu wa amayi  ndi "kulimba kwa mabanja."
mt0: When he announced the new law in March, Prince Mohammed said the law represents "a significant change" in the rights of women and "the strength of families."

en: The reforms seem partly to cater to foreign firms whose investment the kingdom is courting, said Adel al-Saeed, vice president of the European Saudi Organization for Human Rights.
nya: Wachiwiri kwa mtsogoleri wa bungwe la European Saudi Organization for Human Rights, a Adel al-Saeed, ati  kusinthaku mbali ina kupereka mpata kwa ochita malonda a m'mayiko ena omwe zotsatira zake ndi zomwe ufumuwu ukufuna.

en: That knowledge helped when Abbas, 34, was on assignment with Sancha in March 2021. They traveled to a Kurdish-run detention camp in northeast Syria and interviewed female jihadists affiliated with IS, for a story in El Pais.
nya: Kudziwa kumeneku kunathandiza pamene a Abbas a zaka 34, anakagwira ntchito ndi a Sancha mu March, 2021. Iwo anapita ku malo osungira anthu ku Kurdish, kumpoto kwa Syria, kukafunsa mafunso akazi omwe amamenya nawo nkhondo yoyera (yachilungamo) yokhudzana ndi IS, kuti alembe nkhani mu El Pais.

en: "While in Qamishli [in northeast Syria], I ran into two British journalists, very good colleagues of mine, who were disappointed after Shamima Begum and other women at the camp refused to talk to them," Sancha said, referring to a young woman who left her home in Britain aged 15 to join IS.
nya: "Pamene ndinali ku Qamashli (kumpoto kwa Syria), ndinakumana ndi wolemba nkhani komanso anzanga a chi British awiri, omwe anali okhumudwa kuti Shamima Begum ndi akazi ena kumaloku anakana kuyankhula nawo," anatero a Sancha kutanthauza mtsikana yemwe anachoka kwawo ku Britain ali ndi zaka 15 kukalowa gulu la IS.
mt0: When I was in Qamashli (north of Syria), I met with a journalist and two British friends, who were upset that Shamima Begum and other women in the area refused to speak to them," said Sancha, referring to the 15-year-old girl who left Britain to join the Islamic State.

en: "Their fixer was a man, so the jihadist women didnt talk to them because they are radical, and they dont talk to men. But then I was able to sit with Shamima and other women, who gave fantastic interviews from inside their tents," Sancha said.
nya: "Yemwe amawathandiza anali munthu wabambo kotero akazi omenya nkhondowa sanayankhule nawo chifukwa anasintha ndipo sayankhula ndi anthu aamuna. Koma ine ndinakhala pansi ndi Shamima komanso akazi ena omwe anayankha bwino mafunso mkati mwa hema wawo," anatero a Sancha.
mt0: "The man who helped them was a man, so the women who won the war didn't speak to them because they had changed and don't speak to men. But I sat down with Shamima and other women who answered questions in their tent," said Sancha.

en: Unlike Sancha and Gebeily, Abbas grew up in the marginalized Kurdish region of Syria, where until the war began in 2011, journalism effectively didnt exist.
nya: Kusiyana ndi a Sancha ndi a Gebeily, a Abbas anakulira ku chigawo chaching'ono cha Kurdish komwe kunalibe kulemba nkhani kufikira nthawi yomwe nkhondo inayamba mu 2011.
mt0: Except for Sancha and Gebeily, Abbas grew up in a small Kurdish region where there was no newspaper until the start of the 2011 war.

en: "Ordinary people in our region were used to seeing women pick up arms and fight, but they werent used to seeing a woman hold a camera on the streets and on front lines," Abbas said. "It took a lot of sacrificing for me to convince my family and society that Im as good, if not better, as my male colleagues."
nya: "Anthu m'chigawochi anazolowera kuwona amayi akutenga zida ndi kumenya nkhondo osati kuwona amayi atatenga chojambulira munsewu kapena akuyima patsogolo, " anatero Abbas. "Zinatengera kudzipereka kuti banja ndi dera langa atsimikize kuti ndimachita zinthu bwino mwinanso kuposera anzanga achimuna omwe ndimagwira nawo ntchito.
mt0: "People in this region were used to seeing women taking weapons and fighting, not seeing women taking pictures on the road or standing up," said Abbas. "It took me a lot of effort to ensure that my family and my neighbours knew that I was doing well, possibly even better than my male colleagues."

en: Journalism appealed to her because the story of the Middle East has often been told by male journalists, both local and foreign.

en: "The narrative hasnt changed because of that, but if local and international women journalists get a real chance to tell the story of the Middle East, that narrative could change, which would affect the way others see this region," Abbas said.
nya: "Kulemba nkhani sikunasinthe chifukwa cha izi, ngati amayi olemba nkhani a konkuno komanso kunja angapatsidwe mwayi wolemba nkhani za mayiko aluya, kalembedwe ka nkhani kakhoza kusintha, zomwenso zingasinthe mmene anthu ena amawonera chigawo chino," anatero a Abbas.
mt0: "Writing hasn't changed because of this, if women writers from across the world are given the chance to write about developing countries, the writing style can change, which can also change the way people view this area," Abbas said.

en: Sancha also believes women in journalism have an impact on the way issues are viewed in the region, including post-traumatic stress disorder and the effect it has on female health, and subjects such as violence and alcohol.
nya: A Sancha akukhulupilira kuti amayi olemba nkhani ndiwokhudzidwa ndi mmene anthu amaonera zinthu m'chigawochi, kuphatikizapo kukhala ndi maganizo oopsa kamba ka zomwe zinachitika ndi zotsatira zake pa umoyo wa amayi komanso pa ziwawa ndi mowa.

en: "What has happened in Palestine in recent years annuls all plans for compromise with the Zionist enemy (Israel) because no plan for Palestine can be implemented in the absence or contrary to the opinions of its owners, the Palestinians," Khamenei said, speaking in Arabic and addressing Palestinians and other Arabs.

en: As Fewer Americans Attend Church, Can Coffee Shops Fill the Void?
nya: Pamene anthu a ku America ochepa akupita ku tchalitchi, sitolo zogulitsira khofi zitenga malo?
mt0: When few Americans go to church, why do coffee shops take up their places?

en: Churches and other houses of worship have historically played critical social and political functions in American society. But fewer people are attending religious services, and the decline of churches and other houses of worship threatens to leave a void that could potentially be filled by coffee shops.
nya: Tchalitchi ndi nyumba zopemphelera, kwanthawi tsopano zatengapo gawo pa ubale komanso ndale za anthu a ku America. Koma ndi anthu ochepa omwe amapita kopemphera ndipo kuchepa kwa chiwerengero cha ma tchalitchi ndi nyumba zopembedzera kukuopseza kusiya mpata womwe sitolo za khofi zingalowepo.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know Churches and church houses have become a part of American society and politics. But there are few people who go to church and the decline in churches and church houses is threatening to leave a gap that coffee shops could fill.

en: "For so much of American history, the church has really been — or their congregations have really been — essential, providing an unheralded role in providing cohesion and connectedness in communities … encouraging civic engagement and political participation," says Daniel Cox, director of the Survey Center on American Life and a senior fellow at the American Enterprise Institute.
nya: "Mu mbiri ya America, tchalitchi - kapena anthu osonkhanawa- akhala ofunikira potenga gawo mwakachetechete pogwira ntchito limodzi komanso kulumikizana m'dera lawo, kulimbikitsa kuthandiza dera komanso kutengapo mbali pa ndale," atero a Daniel Cox, mkulu wa Survey Centre on American Life komanso mkulu wa American Enterprise Institute.
mt0: "In the history of America, churches - or congregations - have been important in taking a small part in cooperation and collaboration in their community, encouraging assistance to the community and taking part in politics," said Daniel Cox, chief of the Survey Center on American Life and the head of the American Enterprise Institute.

en: "It was not happenstance or luck that the civil rights movement emerged out of the church," Cox says.
nya: "Sikuti zinangochitika kapena kuti ndi mwayi kuti gulu lomenyera ufulu wa anthu linayambira mu tchalitchi," anatero a Cox.
mt0: "It was not just a coincidence or a chance that the rights movement started in the church," said Cox.

en: "And you see that cross-culturally … whether it's in predominantly white rural communities, in the suburbs, wherever, churches have historically been really, really important."
nya: "Mukhoza kuwona kuti pachikhalidwe, kaya ndi ku midzi kwa azungu ambiri kapena madera okulirapo, ndi kwina konse, tchalitchi zakhala zofunika kwambiri.
mt0: You can see that in culture, whether it's in small towns of Europeans or in rural areas, church has always been important.

en: Churches and other houses of worship have also played a role in helping immigrants assimilate once they arrive in America, Cox says.
nya: Tchalitchi ndi nyumba zopemphererako zatenganso udindo pothandiza anthu wobwera kuti akhazikike akafika ku America, atero a Cox.
mt0: If you can't translate simply say you don't know.

en: In 1999, 70% of Americans said they belonged to a church, mosque or synagogue.
nya: Mu 1999, anthu 70 pa 100 aliwonse ku America anati amapita ku tchalichi, ku mzikiti kapena ku kachisi.
mt0: In 1999, 70 per cent of Americans said they went to church, synagogue or temple.

en: By 2020, that number had dropped to 47%. A 2019 survey found that only about three in 10 Americans say they attend weekly religious services.
nya: Pofika 2020, nambalayi inatsika kufika pa anthu 47 pa 100 aliwonse. Kafukufuku wa 2019 wapeza kuti anthu atatu pa anthu khumi aliwonse a ku America ndi omwe amapita kopemphera sabata iliyonse.
mt0: If you can't translate, just say you don't know. By 2020, the number of Catholics fell to 47 per 100. A survey of 2019 found that three per ten Americans went to church every week.

en: Third places  Lack of involvement and affiliation with churches, mosques and synagogues means people might be missing out on what urban sociologist Ray Oldenburg dubbed as "third places" — public gathering spots that offer something that home, the "first place," and work, the "second place," might not.
nya: Malo achitatu, kusakhudzidwa ndi kulumikizana ndi ma tchalitchi, mizikiti komanso ma kachisi kukutanthauza kuti anthu akusowekera zomwe katswiri woona za anthu m'matawuni, a Ray Oldenburg, akutchula kuti "malo achitatu."- msonkhano omwe umapereka zomwe khomo lomwe ndi "malo oyamba" komanso ntchito yomwe ndi "malo achiwiri" sizingapereke.
mt0: If you can't translate the sentence simply say you don't know Three places, without a connection with churches, mosques, and churches means that people are missing what the city's chief sociologist, Ray Oldenburg, calls "three places."- a meeting that provides what the door of the "first place" and the work of the "second place" cannot provide.

en: Oldenburg argued that third places are critical to a communitys social vitality.
nya: A Oldenburg ati malo achitatu amatsutsana ndi maubale komanso umoyo wa anthu m'madera.
mt0: Oldenburg said that the three areas clashed with relationships and health in the communities.

en: An October 2021 survey conducted by the American Survey Center found that commercial spaces like coffee houses foster trust and connection in American communities and could help fill the void left by churches.
nya: Kafukufuku wa mu October, 2021, yemwe anachitidwa ndi gulu la American Survey Centre, anapeza kuti malo ochitila malonda monga nyumba zogulitsira khofi, zimayambitsa kukhulupilirana ndi kulumikizana m'madera a ku America zomwe zinatenga malo a tchalitchi.
mt0: If you can't translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: "If you're a regular at a cafe, the barista may know what you usually order, and they can make it for you, and that feels good," says clinical psychologist Dr. Maria Espinola, an assistant professor in the Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Neuroscience at the University of Cincinnati College of Medicine.
nya: "Ngati umapitapita ku malo omwera khofi, ogulitsa amadziwa zomwe umakonda kugula, amakupangira ndipo izi zimamveka bwino," ananena izi ndi wachipatala woona zokhudzana ndi maganizo, Dr. Maria Espinola, komanso pulofesa wothandizira mu chigawo cha Psychiatry and Behavioral Neuroscience ku sukulu ya ukachenjede ya Cincinnati College of Medicine.
mt0: If you go to coffee shops, they know what you like to buy, they make you feel good," said a psychiatrist and a professor of Psychiatry and Behavioral Neuroscience at the Cincinnati College of Medicine.

en: "It feels good to be recognized, to know that people are expecting you, to know that people care about you, to know that you belong, because the need for belonging and human connection is a fundamental need that we all have, and it's important to have that fulfilled in different ways," Espinola says.
nya: "Zimakhala bwino kudziwa kuti anthu amakuzindikira, akukudikira komanso amasamala za iwe, komanso kudziwa kuti ndiwe m'modzi mwa iwo chifukwa kufuna kukhala m'modzi wa gulu ndi kulumikizana ndi anthu ndi chimodzi mwa zinthu zomwe tonse timafuna ndipo ndikofunika kuti tonse timapeza izi munjira zosiyanasiyana," atero a Espinola.
mt0: If you can't translate the sentence simply say you don't know "It's good to know that people are aware of you, care about you, and that you are one of them, and that you are one of them because the desire to be a part of a group and to connect with people is one of the things we all want and that we all need to get this in different ways," said Espinola.

en: "So, places like third places can allow us to do that."
nya: "Kotero malo achitatu amatilola kuchita zimenezi."
mt0: So three places allowed us to do that.

en: In the past, churches and other houses of worship have been a third place for many Americans.
nya: Kalekale, tchalitchi ndi nyumba zopemphelera zinali malo achitatu kwa anthu ambiri a ku America.
mt0: Early on, churches and prayer houses were a common place for many Americans.

en: In 2019, 67% of people surveyed said they have a third place — a coffee shop, bar, restaurant, park or other place in their community that they visit regularly.
nya: Mu 2019, anthu 67 pa 100 aliwonse omwe anafufuzidwa anapeza kuti ali ndi malo achitatu- malo ogulitsira khofi, malo omwela mowa, malo odyera, malo ochezera kapena malo ena aliwonse m'dera lawo omwe amapitako kawirikawiri.
mt0: In 2019, 67 per 100 people surveyed found that they had three places- coffee shops, restaurants, bars, and other places in their area where they often go.

nya: Amakhulupilira anthu okhala nawo pafupi. Pali ndandanda wa zotsatira zabwino zokhudza ubale zomwe zimalumikizana ndi kukhala ndi malo achitatu…ndipo kwa anthu ambiri a ku America, malowa ndi malo ogulitsira khofi kapena malo omwera.

en: What coffee shops have in their favor is that they can be found almost everywhere, all over the country, and anyone who wants to can stop by regularly.

en: What US Mayors Are Most Worried About After the Pandemic
nya: Zomwe mafumu a mizinda ku U.S akudandaula ukatha mliri
mt0: If you can't translate simply say you don't know what the cities in the U.S. are complaining after the illness.

en: Americas mayors are most concerned about the lingering mental health effects of the COVID-19 pandemic, according to a nationwide survey of 126 mayors conducted during the summer of 2021.
nya: Mafumu a mizinda ku U.S ndiwokhudziwa ndi kutsalira kwa zotsatira za mliri wa COVID-19 pa maganizo a anthu, kutengera ndi kafukufuku wa mafumu a mizinda 126, yemwe anachitika m'dzikolo mu nyengo yotentha mu 2021.
mt0: If you cannot translate simply say you don't know.

en: The respondents headed cities with at least 75,000 residents. The local leaders are still focused on traditional issues such as violent crime, the economy and infrastructure, but they are most concerned about the pandemics long-term impact on the mental health of their constituents.
nya: Oyankhawa amatsogolera mizinda ya anthu pafupifupi 75,000. Atsogoleri a madera ang'ono-ang'ono akanali ndi chidwi pa nkhani monga milandu ya ziwawa, zachuma ndi zomangamanga, koma iwo akukhudzidwa ndi zotsatira za nthawi yaitali za mliri pa maganizo a anthu a misinkhu yonse m'madera awo.
mt0: These respondents are responsible for approximately 75,000 cities. Smaller cities would have been interested in topics such as violence, economic problems, and construction, but they are concerned about the long-term effects of the pandemic on the attitudes of all ages in their communities.

en: Mental health was top of mind for Michael Udine when he was sworn in as mayor of Broward County, Florida, in November 2021.
nya: Thanzi labwino lokhudza maganizo ndilo linali patsogolo pa maganizo a Michael Udine pamene ankalumbira kukhala mfumu ya mzinda wa Broward County, ku Florida, mu Novembala, 2021.
mt0: If you can't translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: "Everything that was a potential issue pre-pandemic has pretty much been exacerbated by the pandemic," he says. "There were issues going into the pandemic, and it was becoming more and more important on everyone's radar screen about the mental health of people of all ages. And I think the pandemic pretty much supercharged those issues."
nya: "Chilichonse chomwe chinali ndikuthekera kokhala vuto mliri usanabwere, zapitilira kukhala mavuto aakulu kamba ka mliriwu," iwo atero. "Panali mavuto pamene mliri unayamba, ndipo kunali kofunikira kuti aliyense azindikire ubwino wa thanzi labwino pa maganizo a anthu a misinkhu yonse. Ndikuganiza kuti mliriwu unawonjezera mavuto amenewa."
mt0: "Everything that was a problem before the illness came, has become a major problem because of the illness," they said. "There were problems when the illness began, and it was important for everyone to understand the importance of good health for a wide range of people's attitudes. I think the illness has added to these problems."

en: It is not unusual for large outbreaks of disease to have a negative impact on mental health, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which reports that rates of anxiety and depressive disorders among adults increased during the pandemic.
nya: Sizachilendo kuti kufala kwa matenda kukhale ndi zotsatira pa maganizo a anthu, kutengera ndi lipoti lomwe bungwe loona za matenda ndi kupewa kwake la Centers for Disease Control and Prevention lapereka, loti chiwerengero cha nkhawa ndi kukhumudwa pakati pa anthu akuluakulu chakwera panthawi ya mliriwu.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: The pandemic has also adversely influenced the emotional and mental health of about one-third of Americas youth.
nya: Mliriwu wawononganso maganizo ndi thanzi lokhudza maganizo a theka la achinyamata ku America.
mt0: The violence has also damaged the attitudes and health of half of the American young people.

en: "What we've seen is just such anxiety, kids who wouldn't ordinarily have a meltdown, because it's so much change and difficulty adjusting to transitions," Maryland psychologist Mary Karapetian Alvord told VOA last month. "We've also seen a lot more sadness and depression."
nya: "Zomwe taona ndi nkhawa zokha, kwa ana omwe samaoneka okhumudwa kale, koma chifukwa cha kusintha kwakukulu,ndizovuta kuzolowera kusintha kwa zinthu," woona za maganizo ku Maryland, a Mary Karapetian Alvord anawuza VOA mwezi watha. "Tawonanso chisoni ndi kukhumudwa kwambiri."
mt0: "What we saw was not only concerns, for children who were not already disturbed, but because of the huge change, it was difficult to adapt to the change," a Maryland researcher, Mary Karapetian Alvord, told VOA last month. "We also saw a lot of sadness and a lot of sadness."

en: Early on in the pandemic, mayors were more focused on city operations, budget shortfalls and the threat the pandemic posed to small businesses, according to David Glick, an associate professor of political science at Boston University and a co-author of the 2021 Menino Survey of Mayors.
nya: Kumayambiliro kwa mliriwu, mafumu a mizinda anali ndi chidwi pa zochitika m'mizinda, mavuto a ndondomeko za chuma komanso chiopsezo chomwe mliriwu umabweretsa pa malonda ang'ono ang'ono, kutengera ndi zomwe anena a David Glick, wothandiza kuphunzitsa zandale ku sukulu ya ukachenjede ya Boston komanso analemba nawo kafukufuku wa Menno Survey of Mayors mu 2021.
mt0: In the early days of the pandemic, mayors were concerned about the cities, economic problems and the potential threat to small business, according to David Glick, a political lecturer at Boston University and a co-author of the Menno Survey of Mayors in 2021.

en: "Some of those concerns still remain, but what we saw more of in 2021 … is concern about some of the long-term impacts on individual residents," Glick says. "Concerns about polarization over vaccines and just people being pushed to their limits … and certainly less on their city budgets and revenues and having to cut programs and some of those types of things that were probably more top of mind earlier in the pandemic."
nya: "Zodandaulitsa zikanalipo koma zomwe tinaona mu 2021…ndi kukhudzidwa ndi zotsatira zanthawi yaitali pa anthu okhala okha," atero a Glick. "Kukhudzidwa ndi kugawanika pa nkhani ya katemera komanso kupanikizidwa kwa anthu…Izi zachititsa kusiya kulabadira kwenikweni za ndondomeko yachuma cha mzinda ndi misonkho komanso kusiya kuchita zinthu zomwe zinali patsogolo kumayambiliro kwa mliriwu.
mt0: If you can't translate the sentence simply say you don't know. "There are concerns but what we saw in 2021...is a concern about long-term effects on the isolated people," said Glick. "The impact of the spread of the vaccine and the pressure on the people...has led to a shift in the financial planning of the city and taxes and has led to a shift in the actions that were already on the agenda at the beginning of the pandemic."

en: Over half of mayors, 52%, are worried about "lingering mental health challenges and trauma," according to the survey. Additionally, more than one-third of mayors, 37%, are worried about learning loss among young people.
nya: Kafukufuku wati mafumu a mizinda 52 pa 100 aliwonse akudandaula za "kutsalira kwa mavuto a mmaganizo ndi mantha obwera kamba ka zochitika zam'mbuyo." Kuwonjezera apo, theka la mafumu a mizinda lomwe ndi 37 pa 100 aliwonse, akudandaula za kusiya kuphunzira kwa achinyamata.
mt0: Research found that 52 per cent of the cities concerned about "the emotional impact and fears of the past." Moreover, 37 per cent of the cities concerned about the youth's educational achievement.

en: "Second only to mental health and trauma, and they're probably not totally independent concerns," Glick says. "It is part of that shift of mayors concerns from immediate threats to businesses closing and people getting sick, to some of these longer-term consequences that are going to persist in the future. And learning loss among their students, theyre worried it's going to persist for many, many, many years into the future. It's hard to make up for."
nya: "Chachiwiri kwa mavuto a mmaganizo ndi mantha obwera kamba ka zochitika zam'mbuyo, ndipo sizokhudza kwenikweni," atero a Glick. "Ndi gawo la kusintha kwa zokhudza mafumu a mzinda kuchoka pa ziopsezo zotseka malonda komanso kudwala kwa anthu kufika pa zotsatira za nthawi yaitali zomwe zidzakhalepobe mtsogolo. Kusiya sukulu kwa ophunzira, kukudandaulitsa zomwe zidzachitike kwa zaka zochuluka zomwe zikubwera kutsogolo. Ndizovuta kubwezeretsa."
mt0: The second problem is fears related to past events, and it's not really about," said Glick. "It's part of the change in the city's governance from the fears of losing business and ill health to the long-term effects that will be present in the future. Leave school for students, makes a serious concern about what will happen in the future. It's difficult to re-establish."

en: According to the survey, other top concerns for Americas mayors include the financial insecurity of low-income residents (33%), the closing of small businesses (29%) and increased crime and violence (26%).
nya: Kafukufuku wati, zina zomwe akudandaula mafumu a mizinda ndi kusowa kwa chuma kwa anthu amene amapeza ndalama zochepa omwe ndi anthu 33 pa 100 aliwonse, kutseka malonda ang'ono angono' omwe ndi 29 pa 100 aliwonse, komanso kuchuluka kwa ziwawa ndi 26%.
mt0: Research shows that some of the problems that the cities are complaining about are the lack of income for the poor, which is 33 per 100, the closure of small businesses, 29 per 100, and the increase in crime by 26%.

en: Just 7% of mayors are worried about the shift to remote work and the long-term impact that could have on outmigration — people moving away from their cities.
nya: Mafumu a mizinda 7 pa 100 aliwonse ndi omwe akudandaula za kusintha kogwilira ntchito kutali komanso zotsatira za nthawi yaitali zomwe zingakhudze kusamuka-anthu kuchoka mmizinda yawo.
mt0: Return only if you cannot translate. If you cannot translate simply say you don't know.

en: The $350 billion in funding from the American Rescue Plan to local and state governments could help mayors address some of their concerns. The survey found that 78% of mayors believe the money will allow them to make meaningful change.
nya: Thandizo la ndalama zokwana 350 biliyoni U.S Dollars lochoka ku bungwe la American Rescue Plan kwa ma boma ang'ono ang'ono ndi ma boma aakulu, likhoza kuthandiza mafumu a mmizinda kuthana ndi ena mwa mavuto awo. Kafukufuku anapezanso kuti mafumu a mmizinda 78 pa 100 aliwonse amakhulupilira kuti ndalama ziwathandiza kusintha zinthu.

The aid of 350 billion U.S. Dollars from the American Rescue Plan for small and large states can help the kings of cities cope with some of their problems. The research also found that 78 per cent of the kings of cities believe that the money helps them change their lives.

en: "What we're seeing is a large majority are using it for things they consider to be transformative and will make major changes to their cities," Glick says, "instead of feeling obligated or feeling the necessity to use it to plug up over-budget gaps to keep the doors open and the lights on."
nya: "Zomwe tikuwona ndi zoti, ambiri mwa iwo akugwiritsa ntchito ndalamazi pa zinthu zomwe akuganiza kuti zikhoza kusintha mizinda yawo," anatero a Glick, "mmalo moona ngati akuyenera kugwiritsa ntchito ndalamazi kuwonjezera ndondomeko yachuma kuti zitseko zikhalebe zotsegula komanso magetsi oyaka."

en: Young Compete Against Old in Hottest US Rental Market in a Decade
nya: Achinyamata akupikisana ndi akulu pa msika wochita lendi nyumba ku U.S mu zaka khumi
mt0: If you can't translate simply say you don't know.

en: Renting an apartment can be a challenge for new college graduates who are facing the hottest U.S. rental market in a decade, along with some unexpected competition from millennials — people aged 24 to 40 — and even baby boomers — the over-57 club.
nya: Kupeza nyumba yochita lendi kukhoza kukhala vuto makamaka kwa omwe amaliza kumene maphunziro awo a ukachenjede pomwe akumana ndi msika wochititsa lendi ku U.S mu zaka khumi, pamodzi ndi mpikisano womwe sanawuyembekezere ndi anthu obadwa mu zaka za pakati pa 1981 ndi 1996, zaka 24 mpaka 40- komanso anthu opitilira zaka 57 omwe anabadwa nkhondo yachiwiri yadziko lonse litatha.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know. Finding a rent-a-house can be a problem especially for those who have just finished their military training when they meet the U.S. rent market in the past ten years, along with a competition that was unexpectedly created by those born between 1981 and 1996, 24 to 40 years, and over 57 years after World War II.

en: "You have aging millennials who are creating families who should be moving from rental situations into ownership but, because of the lack of housing supply, that has been stopped in a lot of instances. And so, what you see is the aging millennial population continues to rent," says Doug Ressler, manager of business intelligence at Yardi-Matrix, a commercial real estate data and research firm.
nya: "Tili ndi anthu a zaka zakubadwa za pakati pa 24 ndi 40, omwe ali ndi mabanja ndipo amayenera kusiya kupanga lendi ndi kukhala ndi nyumba zawo, koma kuchepa kwa nyumba ndikomwe kwaletsa izi. Choncho anthu a zaka zapakati pa 24 ndi 40 akukula pamodzi ndi chiwerengero chawo ndipo akupitiliza kuchita lendi," anatero a Doug Ressler,mkulu wa malonda ku Yardi-Matrix, kampani yogulitsa nyumba komanso yofufuza.
mt0: If you can't translate, just say you don't know.

en: "It's not just about millennials, it's not just about [Gen] Z [people under 24], we also see that boomers are making a transition, he added. "Their percentage of moving into rental properties is growing in the last five years."
nya: "Sizokhudza anthu a zaka 24 mpaka 40 okha ndi [Gen] Z omwe ndi anthu a zaka zosapitilira 24, tikuwonanso kuti anthu a zaka zoposa 57 nawonso akusintha, iwo anawonjezera. "Chiwerengero chawo cholowa m'nyumba za lendi chakhala chikukwera mu zaka zisanu zapitazo."
mt0: If you can't translate simply say you don't know.

en: There are a variety of reasons older people are opting for rentals, according to Ressler.
nya: A Ressler ati palii zifukwa zosiyanasiyana zomwe zikupangitsa anthu achikulire kusankha kukhala pa lendi.
mt0: Ressler says there are many reasons why older people choose to live on rent.

en: "They've lived in a home for so long and they want to be able to reduce their expenses on a fixed income," he says. "They want to live in a social cohort, like a retirement community, and things like that where it's much more socially amenable to them."
nya: "Akhala ku malo osamalira anthu achikulire kwa nthawi yaitali kotero akufuna kuchepetsa ndalama zogwiritsa ntchito kuchoka ku ndalama zomwe amalandira," iwo anatero. Akufuna kukhala pamodzi ndi anthu, malo apawokha, ndi ena otero komwe akhoza kukhala bwino."
mt0: "They have been living in elder care for a long time, so they want to cut costs from their income," they said. They want to live with people, in places alone, and others where they can be happier."

en: The asking price of apartment rentals was up 10.7% in September 2021 compared to last year at the same time, according to the National Association of Realtors (NAR).
nya: Bungwe logulitsa nyumba la National Assembly of Realtors (NAR), lati mtengo wochitira lendi unakwera ndi 10.7% mu September kusiyana ndi nthawi yomweyo chaka chatha.
mt0: If you can't translate, just say you don't know. The National Assembly of Realtors (NAR) says rents rose by 10.7% in September compared with the same period last year.

en: "It's a hot market. We have never seen this market so hot in the last decade," says Gay Cororaton, NARs senior economist and director of housing and commercial research. "The average rent growth, year-over-year, is about 3-to-5%. We're seeing 11% rent growth now, so, clearly, way above trends weve had in the past."
nya: "Ndi msika wotentha. Sitinawonepo msikawu ukuyenda chonchi mu zaka khumi zapitazo," atero a Gay Cororaton, mkulu wa zachuma komanso woyang'anira nyumba ndi kukufuza malonda. "Chiwerenegro cha ochita lendi chimakwera pachaka chilichonse ndi 3 kapena 5%. Tsopano chiwerengerochi chakwera ndi 11%, kupitilira mmene zimakhalira kale."
mt0: "This is a hot market. We haven't seen this market going so well in the past 10 years," said Gay Cororaton, a chief economist and a housing and real estate analyst. "The number of renters rises every year by 3 or 5%. Now it's up by 11%, higher than it was before."

en: Renters are feeling the squeeze because the COVID-19 pandemic caused supply chain issues, slowing down home building in the United States. Instead of the usual 5-to-6 month supply of available single-family homes, supply dropped below two months in January 2021. The lack of housing supply means millennials are having a harder time buying a single-family home, which has been the traditional trajectory in the past.
nya: Ochita lendi apanikizika chifukwa mliri wa COVID-19 umachedwetsa kubwera kwa zinthu, zomwenso zachedwetsa kumanga nyumba ku United States. M'malo mochita ngati kale kuti pa miyezi isanu kapena isanu ndi umodzi nyumba yokhala banja limodzi imakhala yapezeka, tsopano izi zabwerera m'mbuyo ndi miyezi iwiri kuchoka mu Januwale 2021. Kusowa kwa nyumba kukutanthauza kuti anthu a zaka zapakati pa 24 mpaka 40 akuvutika kuti agule nyumba yokhala banja limodzi, ngati momwe zimachitikira m'mbuyomu.
mt0: If you cannot translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: "The whole building industry was beset by supply chain issues," Cororaton says. "Shipments couldn't come in, the price of lumber was rising, manufacturing slowed, workers could not come in [to work], so you have shortages of frames, appliances. So, essentially, just a short supply."
nya: "Ogwira ntchito ya zomangamanga anakhudzidwa ndi mavuto opeza katundu," anatero a Cororaton. "Katundu wochoka kwina samatha kubwera, matabwa amakwera mtengo, kukonza zinthu kumachedwa, ogwira ntchito samabwera ku ntchito, mafelemu ndi zipangizo zina zinachepa. Tingoti pali zinthu zochepa."
mt0: "The construction workers were affected by supply problems," Cororaton said. "The imported goods cannot be delivered, the wood is expensive, repairs are delayed, workers don't come to work, electrical and other equipment is limited. We can say there are few things."

en: The housing supply got even tighter during the pandemic as more investors put their money into housing, according to Cororaton, while existing homeowners looked for second homes.
nya: A Cororaton ati kupeza nyumba kunavutanso nthawi ya mliri pamene anthu ambiri anagwiritsa ntchito ndalama zawo pomanga nyumba pamene anthu omwe ali ndi nyumba kale amayang'ana nyumba zachiwiri.
mt0: Cororaton said that finding a house was also difficult during the crisis when many people used their money to build houses while people who had already built houses looked at houses built by others.

en: "With the pandemic, there was also a big demand for second homes, for vacation homes. Typically, vacation homes accounted for just about 5% [of the market]," she says. "Early this summer they rose to about 8%. So again, strong demand and strong imbalance of demand and supply caused home prices to rise, made them less affordable."
nya: "Malingana ndi mliriwu, chiwerengero cha anthu ofuna nyumba zachiwiri kapena nyumba zokapumulako, chinachuluka. Nthawi zambiri, nyumba zopumulirako zimakwanitsa 5% ya msika," iwo anatero. "Kumayambiliro kwa nyengo yotentha ino panali kukwera ndi 8%. Choncho kukula kwa chiwerengero cha anthu ofuna nyumba ndi kusagwirizana kwa chiwerengero cha wogula ndi wogulitsa ndi komwe kwapangitsa kuti mitengo ya nyumba ikwere, kuchititsa kuti anthu ena akanike kugula.
mt0: "According to the survey, the number of people looking for second homes or vacation houses has increased. Occasionally, vacation houses reach 5% of the market," they said. "The growth of the number of buyers and sellers and the mismatch of the number of buyers and sellers is what has led to the increase in the price of houses, which has led to some people starting to buy."

en: The hottest rental markets right now are in the West and South. More renters are moving to Dallas and Houston in Texas, followed by Atlanta, Georgia; New York; Los Angeles; Austin, Texas; Phoenix, Arizona; and Washington, D.C., according to NAR.
nya: NAR yati misika yochititsa lendi yomwe ikuyenda kwambiri panopa ndi ya kumadzulo ndi ku m'mwera. Ambiri ofuna kuchita lendi akusamukila ku Dallas ndi ku Houston, ku Texas, motsatizana ndi Atlanta ku Georgia; New York ku Los Angeles, Austin ku Texas; Phoenix ku Arizona ndi Washington, D.C.
mt0: NAR says the most popular rental market is the west and south. Most rental seekers are moving to Dallas and Houston, Texas, followed by Atlanta in Georgia; New York in Los Angeles, Austin in Texas; Phoenix in Arizona and Washington, D.C.

en: Cororaton expects the coming year to be a little better but says the housing shortage is likely to continue for the next few years.
nya: A Cororaton akuyembekeza kuti mu chaka chikubwerachi zinthu zikhalako bwino koma kuchepa kwa nyumba kupitilirabe  kwa zaka zingapo mtsogolomu.
mt0: Cororaton hopes that things will be better in the next year but the housing shortage will continue for several years.

en: "You know, the old adage of moving from rentals into homeownership, that whole polemic may be changing," says Ressler. "The sweet spot was always the millennials, and now the millennials are being replaced by the [Gen] Zs, but the millennials are staying longer and the Zs are coming on board, and now you've got the demographic of the boomers … What it means is a very profitable and dynamic [rental] market that's going to continue to grow."
nya: "Mukudziwa kuyankhula kwakale koti kuchoka pa lendi ndi kukhala mwini nyumba, maganizo amenewa mwina akusintha," atero a Ressler. "Omwe amakonda kuchita lendi kale anali anthu a zaka zapakat pa 24 mpaka 40, koma anabwezeretsedwa ndi [Gen] Z, omwe ndi anthu a zaka zosaposera 24. en: Are COVID-19 Restrictions Stunting Children’s Immune Systems?
nya: Kodi ziletso za COVID-19 zikuchepetsa kukula kwa chitetezo mmatupi mwa ana?
mt0: What is the impact of COVID-19 on the growth of immunity in children?

en: Some medical experts have expressed concern that COVID-19 preventative measures, like masking and remote schooling, are potentially weakening childrens immune systems by shielding them from the usual childhood illnesses.
nya: Akatswiri a zaumoyo ena asonyeza kukhudzidwa ponena kuti njira zopewera COVID-19, monga kuvala zotchinga kukamwa ndi kuphunzilira pa intaneti, ndi zomwe zikufooketsa chitetezo cha mmatupi mwa ana chifukwa ana sakudwalanso matenda oyenera kudwala pa umwana wawo.
mt0: Some health experts are concerned that strategies to prevent COVID-19, such as wearing coverings and learning online, are weakening the immune system of children because they don't get the necessary vaccinations for their age.

en: "There are a lot of reasons to believe that kids need to be exposed to things to keep their immunity complex, so that should they encounter something very dangerous, they have aspects of their immunity that might cross over and help protect them against those things," says Sara Sawyer, a professor of molecular, cellular and developmental biology at the University of Colorado Boulder.
nya: "Pali zifukwa zambiri zopangitsa kukhulupilira kuti ana amayenera kuyikidwa poyera ku zinthu kuti chitetezo chawo cha mnthupi chilimbe mu njira zosiyanasiyana, kuti akadzakumana ndi zina zoopsa, adzakhale ndi mbali ina ya chitetezo chawo cha mnthupi yomwe idzathandize kuwateteza ku zinthu zimenezi," anatero a Sara Sawyer, polofesa tinthu tosaoneka, maselo ndi zinthu zamoyo ku sukulu ya ukachenjede ya Colorado Boulder.
mt0: There are many reasons why we believe that children should be exposed to things to begin their immune system to function in different ways, so that when they meet other threats, they will have a part of their immune system that will help them protect themselves from these threats," said Sara Sawyer, a professor of invisible matter, cell and life at the University of Colorado Boulder.

en: At birth, vulnerable infants get antibodies from their mothers breast milk, which helps protect them until they can build their own immunity.
nya: Pobadwa, makanda opanda chitetezo chilichonse amatenga chitetezo kuchoka ku mkaka wa mmawere wa amayi awo omwe umawateteza kufikira nthawi yomwe adzakhale ndi chitetezo chawo.
mt0: If you can't translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: Its no accident that babies start putting things in their mouths as soon as they gain enough dexterity to pick things up.  "They're doing that because they're sampling the environment and building their immunity. That's an evolutionary trait," Sawyer says.
nya: Sikuti ndi ngozi kuti ana amayamba kuyika chilichonse mkamwa mwawo pamene ayamba kutha kugwira zinthu. "Amachita izi chifukwa amakhala akuzindikira malo omwe awazungulira komanso kumanga chitetezo chawo cha mnthupi. Uku ndiye kusintha," a Sawyer anatelo.
mt0: If you can't translate the sentence simply say you don't know.

en: "Theyre exposing their body to germs in a certain, level way to build their immunity.
nya: "Sakubisa thupi lawo kwa tizilombo toyambitsa matenda, mwa njira ina akumanga chitetezo cha mnthupi mwawo.
mt0: "They don't hide their body from bacteria, in other words, they build a barrier against bacteria.

en: So, some people would argue that childhood illnesses, like colds and stomach bugs, build our immunity so that when more dangerous things come along, we're prepared and we don't get as sick from those more dangerous things."
nya: Anthu ena akhoza kunena kuti matenda a ku umwana monga chimfine, kuwawa kwa m'mimba zimamanga chitetezo mnthupi kuti zinthu zina zoopsa zikadzabwera, zidzapeze kuti takonzeka ndipo sitingadwale ndi zinthu zimenezi.
mt0: Some people may say that childhood diseases like fever, diarrhea build up a defense system in the body that will ensure that we are prepared for dangerous things when they come, and we will not be able to get sick.

en: Even before the pandemic, epidemiological evidence suggested that children in more developed countries, where handwashing and the use of sanitizer are more prevalent, might have less-developed immune systems compared to kids in developing nations who are routinely exposed to more bacteria, viruses and allergens.
nya: Ngakhale nthawi imene mliri unali usanabwere, sayansi yoona za kufala ndi kupewa matenda, inachitira umboni kuti ana a m'mayiko otukuka, komwe amasamba mmanja komanso kugwiritsa ntchito mankhwala ophera tizilombo toyambitsa matenda pafupipafupi, atha kukhala ndi chitetezo chofooka mnthupi kusiyana ndi ana a m'mayiko omwe akutukuka kumene omwe amakhala poyera ndi tizilombo toyambitsa matenda komanso kudwala kamba kodana ndi zinthu.

en: This makes kids in more industrialized countries more vulnerable to developing autoimmune diseases, according to whats known as the "hygiene hypothesis."

mt0: This causes children in developed countries to develop diseases that their own body causes based on a hygiene hypothesis.

en: "The hygiene hypothesis is actually quite controversial because it's thought that our exposure to microbes isn't the only factor," says Cody Warren, a virologist and immunologist who is a postdoctoral fellow at the University of Colorado Boulder.
nya: Kafukufuku wa ukhondo, hygiene hypothesis, amabweretsa maganizo osiyanasiyana pomwe ena amati kukhala osabisika ku tizilombo toyambitsa matenda si chifukwa chokha," anatero a Cody Warren, wowona za tizilombo toyambitsa matenda komanso chitetezo mnthupi yemwe anali dotolo wa ku sukulu ya ukachenjede ya Colorado Boulder.

en: "A lot of this could also be dictated by genetics, diet, and the environment that we live in.

en: Warren, the father of three young children, says spending lots of time outdoors is one way to balance the negatives of isolation.

en: "Just exploring microbes in the environment also is benefiting [and] training our immune system," Warren says. "Our immune systems get trained through the foods that we eat, which also have microorganisms on them.
nya: "Kufufuza tizilombo m'malo omwe atizungulira ndikofunika komanso kumalimbitsa chitetezo chathu cha mnthupi," anatero a Warren. "Chitetezo cha mnthupi chimalimba kudzera mu zakudya zomwe timadya, zomwenso zimakhala ndi tizilombo.
mt0: "To find bugs in our environment is important and encourages our overall wildlife protection," said Warren. "Our wildlife protection is strong through our food, which is also filled with bugs."

en: And so, despite the fact that we've kind of been hunkered down a little bit, I do feel that our immune systems will catch up."

en: There are other things parents can do, he says, to boost their childrens immune systems during pandemic times.  "One of the most important things you can do is just to stay up to date on vaccines.
nya: Pali zinthu zina zomwe makolo angachite pofuna kukweza chitetezo cha mnthupi mwa ana awo munthawi ya mliri. "Imodzi mwa zinthu zofunika kuchita ndi kulandira katemela watsopano aliyense."
mt0: "There are some things that parents can do to increase the safety of their children during the pandemic. "One of the things to do is to accept each new patient."

en: That's one of the best ways that we have to train our immune systems," Warren says.

en: "But also, equally important is making sure our children have a good diet and they regulate stress.

mt0: But another important way is to ensure that our children eat healthy foods and get rid of stress.

en: It's been well documented that both of those — having a good diet, a less stressful environment — can have a positive impact on our immune system."

en: New US Rule Grants Automatic Work Permit Extensions to Noncitizens

en: U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) announced Tuesday that it would automatically extend for 360 days the work permits of immigrants who applied to renew their work authorization amid the current backlog in processing times.
nya: Ogwira ntchito yöpereka ziphaso ndi oona zolowa ndi kutuluka mdzikomp lachiwiri analengeza kuti aonjezera pawokha masiku 360 ololeza anthu osamukira mdzikolo kugwirabe ntchito  kamba ka kuchedwa kulongosola mapepala komwe kukuchitika.

en: The new notice expands on the 180-day extension USCIS announced in November. It is expected to prevent about 260,000 immigrants from losing their work permits in the next 18 months. It will also give the agency extra time to clear applicants waiting in line, the agency said in a statement.
nya: Chidziwitso chatsopanochi  chaonjezera pa masiku 180  amene a bungwe USCIS analengeza mu mwezi wa Novembala. Izinso zipereka nthawi yokwanira ku nthambiyo kuti ilongosole ndandanda wa anthu omwe akudikilira kuthandizidwa, nthambiyo inatero.
mt0: The new announcement adds 180 days to the 180 days announced by USCIS in November. This is expected to save 260,000 immigrants from losing their work permits in the next 18 months. This also gives the agency enough time to determine the list of those waiting for help, the agency said.

en: "This temporary rule will provide those noncitizens otherwise eligible for the automatic extension an opportunity to maintain employment and provide critical support for their families while avoiding further disruption for U.S. employers," USCIS Director Ur M. Jaddou said in a statement.

en: The extension, which takes effect Wednesday, aims to stabilize operations for U.S. employers and help people with pending employment authorizations who have a job and are working in the U.S.

en: USCIS is the agency in charge of handling the nation's immigration paperwork. In recent years, it has struggled with backlogs, an issue made worse by the COVID-19 pandemic and budget shortfalls.

en: What Is the US-Launched 'Uniting for Ukraine' Program?

en: U.S. President Joe Biden recently announced the Uniting for Ukraine program, which aims to streamline the process for Ukrainians who have fled their country and are seeking safety in the United States.
nya: Mtsogoleri wa dziko la America a Joe Biden posachedwapa walengeza za ndondomeko ya mgwirizano  wa dziko la Ukraine. Cholinga chake ndi kukonzera njira anthu a dziko la Ukraine amene anathawaa dziko lawo kufuna chitetezo mu dziko la America.

en: The new program, which took effect Monday, will complement existing legal pathways available to those fleeing Russian aggression due to the ongoing Russia-Ukraine crisis, Biden administration officials said.
nya: Ndondomeko yatsopanoyi yomwe inayamba kugwira ntchito Lolemba, iwonjezela njira za malamulo zomwe zidalipo kale kwa anthu amene akuthawa ziwawa za dziko la Russia, akuluakulu a utsogoleri wa a BIden watero.

en: "The U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS) will continue to provide relief to the Ukrainian people, while supporting our European allies who have shouldered so much as the result of Russia's brutal invasion of Ukraine," Secretary of Homeland Security Alejandro Mayorkas said in a statement to reporters on April 21.
nya: “ Chigawo cha malo  ndi chitetezo mu boma la America, chipitiliza kupereka thandizo kwa anthu a ku Ukraine, pamene chikuthandiza Ogwirizana a ku Ulaya amene athandiza kwambiri kamba ka zotsatira za mmene dziko la Russia linalowera mwa upandu ku dziko la Ukraine,” mlembi wa nthambi ya malo ndi chitetezo a Alejandro Mayorka anfotokoza kwa atolankhani mwezi wa Epulo chaka cha 2021.
